PETITION.TITLE: Plant Variety Rights
PETITION.PARA: The Acting Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:
Plant Variety Rights
To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in parliament assembled. We the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth do humbly pray that the Commonwealth government

1. Uphold the principle that the seeds and cuttings of plants are a public resource and a common heritage to all and that accordingly seeds should be freely available to all, freely multipliable, able to be sold, exchanged, exported and imported by anyone who wishes. This is seen as a matter of national food security.

2. Recognise that plant breeding is a highly co-operative venture often involving private enterprise at the very last stages after basic seed collection , storage, and research has been publicly funded.
3. In view of the aforementioned paragraphs, recognise that any system giving ' property' or ownership rights over seeds to individuals, organisations or enterprises is inappropriate and unjust.
4. Recognise that legislation establishing plant patenting schemes overseas has had serious adverse effects namely:
(i) a slowing-down of scientific information exchange and exchanges in basic plant breeding materials, that is, germ plasm,
(ii) subordination and/or curtailment of public breeding programmes,
(iii) farmer unrest at seed prices,
(iv) monopoly control of seed production and sales has passed into the hands of giant petrochemical and drug corporations also marketing crop chemicals,
(v) increased uniformity of crop varieties leading to a vulnerability to pest and disease attack.
5. Reject any proposal to legislate for any system such as the draft Plant Variety Rights Act, which gives exclusive ownership rights over seeds to individuals, organisations or enterprises.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: PUBLIC HOUSING FOR MEMBERS OF PARLIAMENT

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. What is the current Government's policy referred to by Senator Gietzelt yesterday regarding the entitlement of members of parliament to public housing in the Australian Capital Territory? How does the Government justify someone earning the salary of a Federal Minister of about $60,000 occupying a flat at $ 57 a week, which could otherwise be made available as public housing to someone on the Territory's long housing waiting list?

—Since we have been in power the Government has of course been very busy rectifying a disastrous situation in relation to the economy which we inherited. As far as I am aware the Government has not directed its attention to this specific issue which Senator Reid raises. However, I will see that the question is addressed and I will provide her with an answer in due course.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. I ask whether he has seen the article in the Melbourne Herald of 2 April which reported on a submission made by Dr Mendelsohn to the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare inquiry into retirement incomes. Can the Minister comment on the statement reportedly made by Dr Mendelsohn that the pension age for women should be raised from 60 to 65 years on the basis that this would make a significant contribution to financing a national superannuation scheme in the form of a universal age pension for people aged 65 or more?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I did see the article referred to but I have not seen the actual submission of Dr Ronald Mendelsohn to the inquiry. I would like first of all to point out that it is quite incorrect to say that raising the age pension for women from 60 to 65 years would result in substantial savings in social security expenditure which could be redistributed elsewhere. The vast majority of women aged between 60 and 64 years who receive a pension would, particularly in the present economic circumstances, merely be transferred to other social security benefits such as the unemployment benefit, the widow's pension, the deserted wife's pension or similar payments. The overall savings to the Department of Social Security would be in the range, as a rough estimate, of only some $20m a year. I remind honourable senators that to raise the pension by $1 a week would cost $146m a year, so we would not do a lot with that $20m.

ANSWER.PARA: In relation to the other parts of the report-I hasten to add again that my comments are based on that report and not on the full submission-I was most surprised by the reported comment that if a universal pension is introduced the Government should not try to implement its election commitment to raise the basic rate of pension to 25 per cent of average weekly earnings. Dr Mendelsohn seems to be suggesting that these people could be catered for by special needs payments. I assume he means by this that we would have a flat rate pension of a very low level-and it would be a low level-and, added to that, supplementary payments of the type that exist in the United Kingdom for those in particular need. I point out that those special supplementary payments in the United Kingdom are subjected to means tests which are far more rigid than any means test which would ever be applied in this country under the present circumstances . Those payments are considered to be very stigmatising and are considered to be detrimental to the welfare of the recipients. Introducing these payments would thereby recreate the problem that Dr Mendelsohn is presumably trying to eliminate by trying to do away with a means test in this regard. If this approach is rejected we are left with a situation in which Dr Meldelsohn's scheme in fact totally ignores the needs of the vast majority of pensioners currently in receipt of maximum rate pensions who have little or no additional income on top of their pensions and who have no capacity to earn such private income. It also ignores the need of the future aged who cannot afford to save for retirement during their working lives to supplement an inadequate pension of that level. I would have thought that on any measure of fairness these people deserve a higher priority than does a universal pension.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you have responsibilities under the Sex Discrimination Act to treat the sexes equally? It is a serious question.

—All right, it is a serious question so I will give a serious answer. The Department of Social Security is specifically excluded from that legislation. Overall, I am not sure that Dr Mendelsohn's suggested superannuation scheme is the best one to follow. The Government is currently examining a national superannuation scheme but it has great ramifications for investment in this country. It has ramifications in that we all-members of this Parliament plus the rest of the community-have to decide how such a scheme would be financed, and how it would be related to the present age pension and also of course to the existing plethora of occupational superannuation schemes in this country. These problems require serious consideration and debate. I always welcome the contributions of people like Dr Ronald Mendelsohn, whom I know, but I hope that the result of his contribution is to raise the level of that debate and not raise the sorts of expectations or problems which the article reporting his submission to that inquiry has in fact raised.

—Has the attention of the Minister for Industry and Commerce been drawn to the recent survey by the Business Council of Australia which found that while direct wage costs increased by 3.3 per cent last year, labour on- costs rose by a staggering 14.4 per cent? What action, if any, has the Government taken to tackle the problem of labour on-wage costs acknowledged by the Minister at the Metal Trades Industry Association, Inc. function in October last year as being of great seriousness to Australia? If no action has been taken, why has no action been taken?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, my attention has been drawn to the recent survey by the Business Council of Australia and to the figure which it produced in respect of on-wage costs. As Senator Rae will recall, in April or May last year I drew attention to this problem as one which had continually to be addressed. I believe that is so. Since in the Senate I have made the point that it has to be addressed by a number of instrumentalities and organisations in this community, not just the Commonwealth Government, but also State governments and employer and employee organisations, probably the largest single element in on-wage costs now is workers' compensation premiums which have continued to escalate and have been a great burden on Australian industry.

ANSWER.PARA: I was asked a question about this only the other day and made some comment about it. This Government would regard it as an appropriate matter for discussion by the Australian Manufacturing Council and various industry councils because one cannot generalise about it. It has a different burden in different areas. That seems to be the appropriate sort of forum in which those questions should be addressed.

I just add in relation to the question of on-wage costs that in Australia they are not significantly higher than the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development average. In fact, I think they are about the same. I was somewhat surprised last month, for example, when visiting Daimler-Benz in Germany to find that its on-wage costs are running at a level of about 95 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —That probably includes social security contributions.

—Yes, because it makes social security contributions and a variety of other work place contributions as well. Nonetheless, it means that for every dollar which it pays in wages it pays $1.95. I think that question has to be seen in terms of those perspectives.

ANSWER.PARA: I am not able to comment on whether the figures in the Business Council's survey are correct or otherwise or how they are compiled. I do know that the results were drawn to my attention by members of the Business Council and I certainly regard them as a matter of continuing concern.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations aware of any recent strains that have been placed on the prices and incomes accord? In particular, does the Minister know of any proposals being put forward which threaten those sections of the accord which provide for a centralised system of wage fixation, the maintenance of real wages and the sharing of national productivity increases with wage and salary earners?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take it that Senator Childs's question is really addressed to the question of government wages policy and, indeed, other announced alternative wages policies which have been the subject of discussion in the Press quite recently. I am certainly not aware of any proposals to opt out of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. The Government has in place a firm policy, of course, in relation to the prices and incomes accord, which is based on a centralised wage fixation system.

ANSWER.PARA: I must say that according to the Press, after probably what has been the most tortuous and publicised period of gestation in Australian political life, certainly the most tortuous and publicised since perhaps the last royal birth or something of that kind, the Opposition has now given birth to a wages policy, or a so-called wages policy. On my reading of the essential elements of that policy , it emerges as the sickly child of doubtful parentage and, I believe, very limited life expectancy. The reason for that is that it seems to contain a number of inherent contradictions.

TALK.START.PARA: —It sounds like your uranium policy.

—Senator Chaney says that it sounds like the Government's uranium policy as it emerges in the platform, which admittedly is open to a variety of interpretations, as Senator Walsh has pointed out in this place on numerous occasions. The Government's policy, however, is not open to misinterpretation. The Opposition policy on wages is open to a variety of misinterpretations.
—You have not seen it yet.

—I take it that some people have seen it. It has been very widely reported in the Press. If the honourable senator is taking the point that one should not rely on the Press at Question Time, he would not be able to ask a question at all because it seems that he has nothing else to rely on. In this struggle, this great wrangle that has gone on, as the Australian Financial Review describes it, I am not sure which side has actually won. The result seems to be an absolute mish-mash. I believe that the Opposition has settled on a wages policy. This answer might be very useful to members of the Opposition because, as Senator Teague interjected earlier, if the policy has not yet been finalised, they might have an opportunity to brush it up in accordance with my answer. The essential points are that it allows employers and employees to negotiate agreements outside the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and it provides for national wage increases to be awarded in line with national productivity rather than prices.

—I rise on a point of order, Mr President. This is the third question to which the Leader of the Government in the Senate has addressed himself. He was not able to tell the House of the Government's policy on housing or about the occupation of cheap housing by members of the Government. He was not able to tell the Senate whether he had done anything about on-costs, which is an important element of a wages policy. The first matter upon which he has been able to touch discursively upon is wages policy. I suggest that that has nothing to do with his own portfolio responsibilities. He should be called to order and made to answer the question.
—Order! The Minister is answering the question. There is no point of order involved.
—Insofar as this is not a point of order but a political point--
—Order! I am interested only in points of order.

—I simply make the point that this policy contains a number of deficiencies, and these are matters of great concern to the Government because it does not want people in the wider community to be confused by silly notions that might result in some detraction from the benefits of a policy that is set in place and working. I refer to a couple of deficiencies in the policy. Opting out, of course, is unlikely to be agreed to by the employees where that course would mean cuts in wages and conditions, as inevitably it would. If the Commission is asked to deal with that sort of question, how is it to be satisfied that no coercion was exercised in relation to those matters? One would be very concerned to know whether in particular circumstances the Commission would be asked to vary awards in relation to particular companies, which it cannot do, or whether it would be asked to vary awards in relation to an industry. Of course, various elements go to make an industry, and they might include a variety of establishments, some of which, under the criteria suggested by the Opposition, might be eligible for an award variation from which the mass of the industry may or may not benefit. A number of points of that kind are contained in the policy which was reported in the Press. If Opposition senators want to brush up on and improve the policy and extend for another month or two the nine months of wrangling which has taken place to date, it would be of great benefit to them to consider some of these issues. After all, the matter was publicly reported in the Press and it has not been resolved.
—Why don't you tell us about something in your portfolio, like country preferences?

—Senator Rae asks, by way of interjection, why do I not tell the Senate something about my portfolio. The honourable senator has asked perhaps seven questions since we came to government. That shows what the Opposition shadow Minister for Industry and Commerce is doing. If he wants to know about my portfolio perhaps he ought to come to Question Time a little more and ask some questions about it. I am dealing with a question relating to an employment and industrial relations matter on behalf of the Minister whom I represent in this chamber. It is of considerable concern that the Opposition's policy on this matter is, as I say, a mish-mash. From the interjections which have taken place, apparently it has not yet been resolved. Until it is resolved there will be no serious debate about industrial relations and wages issues in this country. For that reason it is a very important matter.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. I ask the Minister, in the light of his purported knowledge of debate within the Opposition parties about these matters, whether he is familiar with the discussions that are taking place within his own Government organisation about the desire on the part of the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations to change the industrial relations and wage fixing system to increase its flexibility. I ask the Minister whether he has taken part in any discussions on whether there should be a move towards limited collective bargaining outside the centralised wage fixing system . Are these matters of debate within the Government, within the Government Party and within the bureaucracy that the Government now controls?
—I am not aware of any discussion--
—That is right.

—Just a minute. I am not aware of any discussion having taken place, as Senator Chaney put it, within my Party or organisation. No discussion has taken place within my Party or organisation in relation to this matter. It does not matter which faction Senator Rae talks about; no discussion has taken place. I am fully aware that the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations has circulated a discussion paper on these issues and, in so doing, has embraced some of the points embraced by Mr Macphee in his side of the continuous wrangle going on within the Opposition to which I was referring earlier in Question Time when I was interrupted by interjections. I am quite aware of the circulation of that paper. It is an important contribution to the debate on wages policy. I look forward to the day when the Opposition can make an important contribution to the debate on wages policy. It seems a long way off .

—I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the President's gallery of Dame Nancy Buttfield, a former distinguished senator from South Australia, and, in the public gallery on my right, the presence of Mr Neville Bonner, a former distinguished senator from Queensland. On behalf of all senators I extend to both of them a warm and friendly welcome to Canberra.

—Can the Minister representing the Treasurer inform the Senate how many applications for new taxation file numbers the Department of the Treasury has received since the introduction of the prescribed payments taxation system on 1 October last year? Of this number, how many applications were from people or companies who had previously not registered with the Australian Taxation Office or paid any taxation? From the information available to the Minister, is he in a position to state whether any of the people in this category were operating in their various industries prior to the commencement of the prescribed payments taxation? Finally, do the early figures suggest that the prescribed payments legislation has been a successful measure in combating a major portion of the only growth industry in Australia during the Fraser years, the tax avoidance industry?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a note from the Treasurer on this matter. All the figures state the position as at 9 March; they are the most recently available figures. They show that almost 43,000 applications for new taxation file numbers have been received. It is not possible at this stage to say how many of those were from applicants who had been obliged to lodge returns before but had not done so . But the early indications are that something like 25 per cent of those 43,000 applicants had not previously lodged income tax returns even though they had a liability to do so. Of the balance of the other 30,000-odd, some are individuals who claimed to have newly arrived in Australia, but most are new entities like partnerships, trusts and companies in relation to which it seems reasonable to expect or to assume that the proprietors had commonly previously had a liability to lodge returns but had not done so. The vast majority of defaulters detected so far had been operating in the respective industries prior to the introduction of the prescribed payments system.

ANSWER.PARA: It is too early to gauge the overall effectiveness of the prescribed payments system, but it is evident that the system has been extremely successful in bringing to light large numbers of taxpayers who have evaded tax in the past by failing to lodge returns, which I think explains the vociferous campaign waged last spring to torpedo the necessary legislation, a campaign which I note with regret was supported by a number of Liberal and National Party politicians, concentrated, as is usual for campaigns on behalf of tax evaders, in Western Australia. The actions of such people were at best opportunistic and at worst something much worse.

On Senator Richardson's final comment about the growth rate of various industries in Australia it is perfectly clear-as he said, the only growth industry under the Fraser Government, at least in its final years, was of course the tax avoidance industry-that almost every industry other than the tax avoidance industry has grown at quite a spectacular rate since the Fraser Government was dispatched to the dustbin of history. The one industry which has not fared at all well under this Government, and indeed would become extinct were it not for the obstructionist actions of half the members of the Senate, is the tax avoidance industry. That industry has fared very badly under this Government. Regrettably, the actions of half the members of this Senate have precluded the Government from ensuring that that industry becomes extinct.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Resources and Energy and concerns an answer he gave yesterday to a very gentle, helpful and soothing question which he received from his new admirer, Senator Sir John Carrick. In his answer Senator Walsh said:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . although it is technically feasible to produce weapons grade plutonium from a power reactor, there is no known instance of that having been done, at least in the non-communist world.

Has the Minister forgotten-Senator Mason drew his attention to it last year-that the United States Energy Research and Development Administration officially confirmed on 4 August 1977 that the United States of America had constructed and exploded a nuclear bomb made from reactor grade plutonium. Will the Minister correct his statement which, although no doubt made in good faith, was a stark case of misleading the Senate?

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not aware of the particular case that Senator Chipp has cited . I will have it checked out. In the answer that I gave yesterday I explained how one could expedite production of an explosive device via a power reactor if the rods were subject to intensive and short term irradiation. But that, of course, is not the way in which power reactors are operated. For one reason, they would not produce much electricity if they were operated in that way. But as to the specific case that Senator Chipp raised and the nature of the device which, according to his information, was produced, I will have that checked out and supply him with an answer either in the Senate or in writing, whichever he prefers.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: UNIVERSITY OF SYDNEY: NEW SOUTH WALES ANTI-DISCRIMINATION LEGISLATION

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs. Did the Minister see the remarks made by Professor John Ward, Vice- Chancellor of Sydney University, as reported in yesterday's Australian? Did Professor Ward complain about the high cost to the University of Sydney of complying with the equal opportunity provisions of the New South Wales anti- discrimination legislation and strongly criticise the State Government for requiring the University to implement the State law. While admitting that equal opportunity and anti-discrimination laws are widely supported in the University, did Professor Ward say that money which would have to be spent on implementing the legislation was needed for teaching and research? Can the Minister comment on the suggestion that the implementation of affirmative action proposals in tertiary institutions will take money away from education and research?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I saw Professor Ward's comments as reported in the Australian and other newspapers yesterday. They were along the lines set out in Senator Sibraa's question. I must say that although I welcome the entry into debate by administrators of tertiary institutions, on matters of social importance such as equal opportunity, it is a little disappointing when they find it necessary, as Professor Ward apparently did, to be so negative about such an important social reform. One would hope that universities particularly, which are supposed to be places of enlightenment and perhaps more carefully developed social values, would be places where such social reforms would be more welcome than in the community at large.

ANSWER.PARA: Professor Ward was reported as mentioning a figure of half a million dollars as the cost of implementing an equal opportunities management plan as required by the New South Wales Government's anti-discrimination legislation. The major requirement of that legislation is the production and implementation of an equal employment plan. I find it very difficult to conceive how, in any institution which already carries out efficient management planning, such a cost could be incurred. Some extra cost for items such as record keeping, staff training and staff development for the plan would be incurred. However, I would be very surprised if these costs came to anything like the amount mentioned by Professor Ward. There may be some once only costs involved in setting up the first equal employment opportunity management plan. I have asked the Commonwealth Teritary Education Commission to seek a breakdown from Professor Ward of the costs involved.

With regard to our own Government's intentions in this direction, our affirmative action Green Paper, which will be released soon, will discuss the possibility of similar management plans for tertiary institutions around Australia. However, I should point out that there are significant differences between what the Federal Government is considering and the requirements of the New South Wales legislation. The New South Wales legislation, to which Professor Ward was referring, covers not only women but also other groups such as Aboriginals and migrants and, thus, the costs involved would be greater than under proposals under consideration by us. The New South Wales legislation also has specific requirements with regard to information acquisition which will not necessarily be taken up in our proposals.

I would like to mention the cost to education, to our economy and to our society generally of not utilising the full potential of women and other groups such as migrants and Aboriginals. It is my belief that the quality of teaching, research and education in general will be greatly improved by utilising these currently untapped resources. So, far from being a net cost to the public, I think such social reforms in fact have many net benefits not only to universities but also to the labour market and to our society generally.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Will the alterations to the Commonwealth Banking Corporation announced by the Treasurer yesterday severely restrict the operations of the Commonwealth Development Bank of Australia? Will this in fact reduce finance to small business instead of increasing it as was promised by the Government before last year's election?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Commonwealth Development Bank, as Senator Scott implied in his question, had $75m transferred from its reserves to the Commonwealth Bank of Australia, but it is the view of the Government and I believe of officials of the Commonwealth Bank, certainly those with whom I have discussed the matter, that that will not adversely affect the ability of the Commonwealth Development Bank to supply finance for small business needs in the foreseeable future. Senator Scott will recall that the role of the Commonwealth Development Bank was the subject of discussion by the Review of the Australian Financial System, the Martin committee report, to which the Government has yet to respond.

ANSWER.PARA: Because the Commonwealth Development Bank paid neither tax nor dividend on its profits to the Commonwealth, it had accumulated large reserves of some $79m at 30 June 1983 and total capital and reserves at that date were at a figure in excess of $200m. It is considered that because the Government increased the gearing ratio of the bank at the time of the May economic statement last year, as I recall, or maybe at the time of the Budget-I am not clear in my recollection-the reduction of $75m in Commonwealth Development Bank reserves will still leave it with plenty of reserves to carry on its function as a lender to small business, and particularly to primary producers.

Last week I was present at a Commonwealth Development Bank function at which a number of these issues were discussed with representatives of farming organisations. No particular concern was expressed when the explanations I have just given to the Senate were made to representatives at that function.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Science and Technology. What further Commonwealth assistance can be given to South Australia to help end the portuguese millipede infestation in and around Adelaide and in the Adelaide Hills? It is claimed that money is still needed to test the effectiveness of a natural enemy, identified in Portugal, its effect on the environment and whether there will be other side effects. As the millipede has recently been found in Victoria and Tasmania, what can the Minister now say about further Commonwealth Government assistance to eradicate this problem?

—I am very pleased to inform the Senate that certain information on the subject of the portuguese millipede in South Australia has been provided to me by my colleague. The funding of a joint Commonwealth-South Australian three- year study into the biological control of the millipede ended in December 1983; the funding was on a 50-50 basis. The project involved the recruitment of a research scientist of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation who had already studied the millipede for his PhD thesis. There is a serious problem. The information provided to me by my colleague is very full and, even though it is of great interest to the Senate generally, it is probably of particular interest to Senator Maguire. Therefore, I shall provide him with the long and detailed information provided to me rather than provide it to all honourable senators.

—Will the Minister for Industry and Commerce confirm that on 6 October last year he announced two major inquiries into the Australian motor vehicle industry-one an Industries Assistance Commission reference foreshadowing lower protection for light commercial vehicles, and the other establishing a car industry council to examine key aspects of the post-1984 passenger vehicle policy? Is it not also true that Senator Button at the same Press conference said that both inquiries would report by mid-December and lead to government decisions by February? As that time has now well and truly passed, I ask: When will the Government's decisions on the motor vehicle industry be made and when will they be announced?

—It is true that two inquiries were announced on 6 October-the reference to the IAC relating to light commercial vehicles and the appointment of the Car Industry Council, which was not a government body but an industry body which, hopefully, was designed to provide some self-help remedies to the industry's problems. The IAC has reported and the Car Industry Council reported in December. Arising particularly from the second report are a number of further considerations which the Government has to take into account. I am not at this stage in a position to announce a precise date on which there will be a government response to both matters. The resolution of the problems has been considerably complicated by the fact that the five plant manufacturers in Australia are all foreign-owned corporations and there is a necessity for discussions to take place in some instances not only with the local companies but also with the parent companies. However, as soon as I am able to advise a definite date on which an announcement can be made I will be happy to advise Senator Teague.

—I direct a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Aviation. Has the Independent Air Fares Committee presented a detailed report on its reasons for recommending a 2 per cent increase in air fares on 2 April? If so, is that report publicly available? If not, will a report be made available so that the travelling public and elected representatives are able to scrutinise the Committee's assessment?

—Honourable senators will be aware that in the last couple of days a report has been published in the Press that a general increase of 2 per cent has been approved by the Independent Air Fares Committee for fares associated with Ansett Airlines of Australia and Trans Australia Airlines on their jet services. I understand that the Independent Air Fares Committee has had a major air fare review. Under the provisions of the Act, of course, it has the independence and the capacity to do that following representations made to it by the appropriate airline operators. It is committed not only to publish its findings but also to make available the evidence and its reasons for coming to certain conclusions. It is required to have published in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette a notice setting out the terms of the determination, the reasons for making it and any findings or facts placed before it. However, I have to inform Senator Colston that the Committee has not as yet published its findings although they will be available in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette. That will be done in a very short space of time.

—Is the Minister for Social Security aware of reports that medical fraud and overservicing, while apparently marginally decreasing, are still costing the Government at least $130m per year in lost revenue? Further, is the Minister aware of recent allegations that this loss of revenue is at least partly due to the fact that the fraud and overservicing detection section of the Department of Health is understaffed? Given that there is now a significant number of staff in the Department of Social Security who have become surplus to requirements because of the Prime Minister's decision to refer the proposed assets and income test legislation to an independent inquiry, will the Minister consider lending, or whatever one does with underdeployed staff, to FODS those DSS staff who have not yet been deployed in other areas so that a more vigorous and extensive pursuit of medical fraud and overservicing can be undertaken?

—I am aware that fraud and overservicing cost the Government money and that progress is slower than the Minister would like in overcoming that problem. The problem is not only lack of staff, but also, as I am sure the honourable senator knows, the time taken to detect, charge and do all the other things that we have to do to people who are overcharging. Since the deferment of the assets test and its referral to a panel the Department has been redeploying staff. The staff have gone first of all to those departments which requested that they be transferred; namely, the Department of Housing and Construction, which as the honourable senator knows has a backlog with the first home ownership scheme; the Australian Taxation Office, which recruits people at this time of the year; and the Department of Primary Industry. Those are the only departments involved, so far as I can remember. I cannot remember a request from the Department of Health. That redeployment, combined with the fact that there is a wastage of something like 300 people every month from the Department of Social Security, has meant that we are well on the way to redeploying all those people who were excess to our needs. However, I will again draw to Dr Blewett's attention the fact that those staff are available, and the good advice of Senator Haines, who believes that those people can assist him with his problem, to see whether we can make some arrangement. But of course it does depend on the skills of those people who are available from my Department.

—I ask the Minister for Veterans' Affairs whether his attention has been drawn to newspaper and radio reports of a scientific study into the link between birth defects and Vietnam service. Does the Minister accept the findings of that study which conclude that there is no statistical evidence of such a link?

—Yes, I have in the last couple of days read of and heard of the scientific study referred to by Senator Reynolds. It appears that the reports arose as a result of articles which appeared in the Medical Journal of Australia dated 31 March 1984. These articles summarised the results of a survey and detailed the results of a birth defects study carried out by Australian Veterans Health Studies, which was released by Senator Messner on 20 February last year and reported to the Senate on 11 May 1983. The main conclusion of that report was that there was no evidence that Vietnam Army service by the father increased the risk of a birth abnormality in the child. I think the incredible fact about the publication of the articles referred to is that they are the result of a report which is almost a year old. The articles in the Medical Journal of Australia and in the newspapers make no reference to the fact that the Government report was rejected by the Vietnam Veterans Association. The Association has been very critical of the study and the way in which the report was conducted. I remind the Senate that it was an interim report, in that both the report and these criticisms are being investigated by the Royal Commission on the Use and Effects of Chemical Agents on Australian Personnel in Vietnam. In those circumstances it would be inappropriate for me to make any comment on the findings of the birth defects study. However, the re-publication, the regurgitation, of these reports created some concern among and criticism by the Vietnam veterans. It is a matter of some regret that a report which is so old has been rehashed in such a way as to create the impression that it is the latest report and one that is associated with the current Royal Commission. I assure Senator Reynolds that that is not the case, that the report has no particular relevance to the current inquiry being conducted by the Royal Commission. If any distress has been caused to the veterans-I believe some has- it is to be deprecated that the journalists who wrote the story did not bother to check the basic facts; namely, the report is a year old and other studies may be conducted by the Royal Commission into the problems associated with chemical agents in Vietnam.

—I ask the Minister for Industry and Commerce: Is it a fact that Senator Tate, on behalf of the Government, gave a commitment on 8 September 1983 to indicate by a ministerial statement the substance of the review of petroleum retailing legislation? Has the Minister had the review since November last year? When will the report of the review be released and when will the Government announce its decision on the review?

—I have no idea what Senator Tate did on 8 September 1983. As a matter of fact, I feel it would be presumptuous of me to inquire. On the assumption that Senator Tate did make such a statement, I am able to indicate that the review and the Government decision on it will be published within two weeks.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. What sums of money have been allocated to community employment program projects undertaken in Queensland? How does the rate of absorption of those funds for the program in Queensland compare with that of other States and how many unemployed people have been employed so far on CEP projects in Queensland? Is the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations satisfied with the general response and level of assistance being given by the Queensland Government in the administration of the program in that State?

—I am able generally to answer yes to those questions; that is to say, although there was perhaps a somewhat shaky start in Queensland in relation to the various parts of the question asked by Senator Jones, the answer is generally that yes, the progress of the CEP in Queensland is satisfactory. I do have, though not with me, some statistics which illustrate the answer I have just given, and I will make those available as soon as I can, perhaps at the end of Question Time.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: 'THE STRATEGIC BASIS OF AUSTRALIA'S DEFENCE POLICY'

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

I refer the Attorney to the Prime Minister's statement in the House of Representatives yesterday in answer to a question concerning the strategic defence basis document. QUESTION.PARA: I note that that crucially important sentence does not appear in the extracts in the National Times.

TALK.START.PARA: —No.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health. Has the Minister seen the figures for bulk billing under Medicare for the first seven weeks of Medicare's operation, showing that 48.5 per cent, or 4.4 million, of 9.1 million services performed have been bulk billed? The percentages are 51.8 per cent for New South Wales and 48.5 per cent for South Australia. Does the Minister agree that these figures indicate a high acceptance by doctors of the principle of Medicare and does he agree that these figures contradict the public image of Australian Medical Association opposition to Medicare and AMA insistence that Medicare is back-door nationalisation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the figures put out by the Minister for Health. As Senator Crowley says, there is considerable acceptance of bulk billing although in some areas, particularly in Tasmania, my own State, and the Australian Capital Territory, the percentage of doctors bulk billing is very low. This indicates that many members of the medical profession, particularly general practitioners, accept that bulk billing is desirable for large groups of people, not only pensioners and beneficiaries but also disadvantaged people, and that others accept that bulk billing is a good thing for everybody, including the doctors themselves.

ANSWER.PARA: While we have the spokesman for the Australian Medical Association and the General Practitioners Society and others saying that the basis of their opposition to Medicare is that it is back-door nationalisation, socialisation or whatever other colourful term they want to use and that the real basis of their objection is to bulk billing, we find that while they are saying one thing their colleagues are doing another. That was the history with Medibank; that was the history with the Canadian national health scheme; and it will be the history of Medicare in this country. The percentage of services bulk billed will continue to increase.

In those smaller States or Territories, the Australian Capital Territory and Tasmania, where there are smaller numbers of doctors in smaller areas who can get together and provide each other with all sorts of moral support and, to use a phrase of Senator Teague's last night, some might even use coercion, we will always get this initial low compliance rate with bulk billing. But as I say, as Medicare is in place and gets more acceptance from the community and the doctors , bulk billing will increase and that will be the proof of the pudding.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ARMY FIRING RANGE: SHIRE OF COBAR

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Resources and Energy. It concerns the possibility that an Army firing range might be constructed on top of the Sydney-Moomba gas pipeline. I ask the Minister: Is he aware that there is a proposed acquisition of about 2 million hectares of land in or near the Shire of Cobar in my State for the development of an Army manoeuvre and field firing area? Is it not a fact that the Sydney-Moomba natural gas pipeline passes through the proposed manoeuvre and field firing area? Is not a field firing area a place where live ammunition is likely to be found? Is not an Army manoeuvre area an area where tanks and other vehicles are likely to pass ? Are there not very serious restrictions, safety rules, which apply to people living close to the pipeline? I ask the Minister whether it is possible, having regard to the proper safety of the pipeline, to envisage allowing a field firing range or an Army manoeuvre area, for example for the movement of trucks or tanks , to be established at or near any area close to the pipeline.

—Yes, some two or three weeks ago I was given a minute on this, which said that there was a proposal in that area to establish a training area of the type Senator Baume suggested. The facts at that stage were not entirely clear as to whether it was adjacent to or close to the pipeline or whether it actually straddled the pipeline area. I still do not know precisely what the proposition is or indeed whether there was a firm proposition as far as the Army is concerned. If it should be dangerously close to or straddling the area, however, the Pipeline Authority has taken the question up. I will make further inquiries to see what the latest information is and make it available. But the Pipeline Authority is aware at least of the potential danger-I would go beyond saying 'potential danger' and call it a prima facie danger-of having military or explosive activity in an area anywhere close to the pipeline.

—My question is to the Minister for Social Security. I refer him to the details of unemployment beneficiaries that he provided to the Senate last Friday. Has the Minister seen today's report that the decrease in unemployment in South Australia over the last three months has exceeded that of all other Australian States? In view of this information, does the Minister have any further information, any more recent statistics, on the number of unemployment beneficiaries in Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —My attention has been drawn to an Australian Associated Press report this day pointing out that the number of South Australians on unemployment benefit between January and March fell at a rate faster than the rest of Australia. In other words, it fell by 9.3 per cent compared with 0.1 per cent. These figures were put out by the State Government's economic unit. My only comment on those figures is that they are correct and that it is very cheeky of the State Government's economic unit because it pinched them from the answer that I gave in this place last Friday.

ANSWER.PARA: But I have further knowledge and further information about the unemployment beneficiaries which is important. In the week ending Friday, 30 March, the number of unemployment beneficiaries in this country actually declined by 7,000 to 626,200. In the corresponding week last year the number increased by 6,700. The most significant point about the figures is that the total number of unemployment beneficiaries is now some 3,000 fewer than the figure for the corresponding time last year, and this is the first time that that has happened. These figures show that in just over 12 months in office the Government has been able to reverse the seemingly inexorable increase in the number of unemployment beneficiaries that took place under the previous Government and immediately after the previous Government was removed from office.

—I address a question to the Minister for Social Security. A letter in the Melbourne Herald recently stated that the Australian Labor Party Government is currently reducing funding in real terms to women's refuges and child care. Would the Minister clarify the Government's policy in these areas?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I saw a letter to that effect in the Melbourne Herald last week. It was written by Eve Mahlab, a well-known and well-respected member of the Liberal Party.
—She is very critical of the current leader, too.

—Indeed she is. She is also critical of the present Government in respect of these two areas of women's refuges and child care. Her criticism is not justified, unlike her criticism of the present Leader of the Opposition. In fact, as I think most honourable senators know, in the area of children's services last year the Government increased expenditure on new projects by $11m. In the area of women's refuges the Government introduced a women's emergency services program, with the provision of another $4m in the current year to assist those much exploited women who run women's refuges. I have just approved the expenditure of the first of that money.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government made a commitment in the last Budget to increase expenditure on children's services this year. It has also given a commitment to continue the women's emergency services program. On both those scores Miss Mahlab is wrong. She has probably been misled by the propaganda from her own Party.
I note that she also advocates the introduction of tax deductions for expenditure on child care, children's services.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—That may be the policy of good working women on high wages, such as Senator Haines. In fact, it is a poor way to distribute money in this area. The funds allocated to this area need to be distributed to those in need, which includes those who are working and those who are not working. The distribution of funds should be equitable. Therefore I personally do not favour the introduction of tax deductions for expenditure on child care because such a system would benefit only those who are working and, in particular, those who receive the sorts of wages that Senator Haines receives.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: PUBLIC HOUSING FOR MEMBERS OF PARLIAMENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier today in Question Time Senator Reid asked me a question about Tom Uren's house. I was asked particularly what the Government's policy was on this issue and whether I recalled any deliberations by the Government about it. I said no, that the Government had been too busy involving itself with other matters relating to the economy. I am able to say that the policy of the present Government is one which has been, in a sense, inherited from previous governments. It was a policy established in 1956 by a Liberal-National Country Party coalition and has been followed by successive governments since that time. Under that policy Mr Uren, as a Minister, is entitled to government housing. Since 1956, 25 Ministers have had tenancies in their names. Mr Uren has been a tenant of the present house which he occupies since 1973.
—He is the last.

—Yes, he is the last of the 25 Ministers who have had houses under those circumstances. He obtained and retains his accommodation strictly in accordance with long established rules in relation to housing in the Australian Capital Territory for Ministers and continues to do so for that period. I say that by way of background as it were to the question which was asked of me by Senator Reid, merely to indicate that there is no change of Government policy in relation to ministerial use of government houses, that Mr Uren remains the last survivor of a policy established by conservative governments and carried on ever since.

—In Question Time today Senator Jones asked me a question about the operation of the community employment program in Queensland. I said that the program was operating satisfactorily in Queensland. I just add to that by saying that the Queensland Government has told the Federal Government that it expects to meet its target expenditure of $41.268m by 30 June this year. The applications received in that State to 9 March under the CEP have totalled 1,379 . The Commonwealth Government has indicated that it is pleased with the overall progress in Queensland and the general response and assistance which has been given by the Queensland Government in the administration of the program. As at 9 March this year, 4,603 jobs were approved in Queensland involving 606 projects. It is estimated that to 23 March 1984, 1,700 unemployed people have been employed under the community employment program in Queensland. I am delighted to inform the Senate that that program is working well in Queensland. Initially it was opposed by the Queensland Government and was not given great support. It is a great Commonwealth Government initiative. The Queensland Government is to be congratulated on co-operating in that Commonwealth initiative for the benefit of the people of Queensland.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier today in Question Time Senator Maguire asked me a question concerning proposed Commonwealth assistance to South Australia to deal with the millipede infestation problem. Because the information I had from my colleague Mr Barry Jones was long and detailed I undertook to give that information to Senator Maguire. However, subsequently it was drawn to my attention that many honourable senators in this place would appreciate access to this long and detailed information on the problem of the Portuguese millipede. I now seek leave to have the information incorporated in Hansard.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The information read as follows-
Funding for a joint Commonwealth/South Australian three-year study into the biological control of the millipede ended in December 1983. The funding was on a 50/50 basis.

The project involved the recruitment of a research scientist to CSIRO who had already studied the millipede for his PhD thesis. He spent the greater part of the three years in Portugal (the millipede's region of origin) searching for natural enemies that showed potential for controlling the pest in South Australia and studying their life cycles. The most promising organism identified was a parasitic fly whose larvae feed and pupate inside the millipede.

The next stages would be to collect supplies of the parasitic fly in Portugal, introduce them under quarantine into Australia, develop methods for mass rearing under laboratory conditions, test the fly's specificity to the millipede and whether it is likely to attack other hosts, make field releases in the infested areas, and monitor the effectiveness in controlling the millipede.

To keep the project moving, South Australia has offered to finance a $4,000 collecting mission to Portugal by the CSIRO scientist to gather supplies of the parasitic fly. It is intended that this will occur next August which is the most suitable time having regard to the reproductive cycle of the fly. The scientist would then supervise the project's succeeding stages outlined above which would be carried out in Australia rather than Portugal.

Although the scientist is presently in the early stages of a project on the biological control of pest snails in South Australia, he will work on the millipede project as necessary. This will represent a Commonwealth contribution to the solution of the problem in terms of time, expertise, and salary and operating expenses.
If further funds are required, at a later stage, CSIRO will approach appropriate authorities.

That may be his problem; he may be in his room preparing questions on notice. But that was the allegation I made and I regard it as a factual one.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I seek leave to make a personal explanation as I claim to have been misrepresented.

He said that clause 7 stated:

(a) in the name of the Doctor charge the intermediate patients of the Doctors fees for medical, pathological, radiological and other diagnostic services performed by him/her according to the specified fee as prescribed from time to time in Schedule 1 of the Health Insurance Act . . .

The doctors signed that document to ensure that the fee charged was the schedule fee. The document was signed on 7 October 1983, just a few months ago. Senator Walters said that the doctors did not sign any such document.

The doctors who agree with it and those who work in the Royal Hobart Hospital-and every other public hospital in Tasmania-are listed on the back of the schedule, although I point out that-

The doctors in Tasmania signed the document, thereby agreeing that only the schedule fee would be charged by them. We are told that it was signed by those four doctors on their behalf and on behalf of every doctor in the State.

As I have said, that is not possible and not accurate.

—by leave-Last night I spoke in response to a statement by Senator Walters, in response to an interjection by me, that doctors in Tasmania did not in fact sign an agreement, that doctors did not have any agreement that the schedule fee would be charged for their intermediate patients. In answer to that, I demonstrated that that in fact occurred at the biggest and most prestigious hospital in Tasmania. I have since discovered today that that also applies to Launceston General Hospital and the North Western General Hospital. Senator Walters was making the point last night that it did not apply anywhere in Tasmania. She was quite wrong; quite inaccurate. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

The list circulated to honourable senators indicates that the annual report of the Australian War Memorial is in a typescript form and that limited copies of the report are available from the Bills and Papers Office, the Parliamentary Library and the Senate Records Office. It also points out that final printed copies of the report are expected to be available for circulation to honourable senators towards the end of April 1984. I obtained a copy of this draft report from the Senate Records Office. The list which was circulated yesterday contained a statement from the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment (Mr Cohen). Time did not allow us to discuss that statement. When that paper comes up for discussion tomorrow I shall make some comment in relation to the timing of the annual report of the Australian War Memorial because it is relevant in the context of the statement by the Minister for Home Affairs tabled in the Senate yesterday.

Today I will confine myself to the contents of the draft report of the Australian War Memorial. The report notes that a number of major achievements were made in the course of the 1982-83 financial year including a grant of $11. 5m over the full year from 1982 to 1983 for major building improvements and extensions, an increase of 30 in the full time staff ceiling and a very substantial increase in the Memorial's appropriation from $3,447,900 to $5,328, 000. This allocation, of course, was contained in the 1982-83 Budget, the last Fraser Budget. I welcome the fact that the then Government recognised the needs of the War Memorial and made substantial increases in grants in relation to capital funds, normal appropriations and staff.

The Australian War Memorial has developed as one of the major attractions of Australia and probably the major attraction of Canberra. I am informed that the Memorial attracts more than one million visitors each year. I am well aware that , together with the National Library of Australia and Parliament House, it is a feature of trips by school groups to Canberra. The Australian War Memorial has become world renowned and for international visitors a visit is a must. As a consequence, the demands and strains on the facilities of the War Memorial were considerable and a building program and an increase in staff became necessary. As I have said, those matters were contained in the 1982-83 appropriation in the last Fraser Budget. Nevertheless, as is pointed out in the report, there is a need for some further expansion, particularly in the staffing area.

The report will give senators an idea of the very wide range of activities of the War Memorial and the way in which a number of those activities are carried out with great distinction. For example, last year the Memorial received one of the awards for museums in Australia in the category related to education, which was recognition of an important function of the Memorial. It is not just a museum which gives us information about Australians at war; it is not just a memorial to Australians who have fought for their country in war. It is also an important function of the Memorial that it carries out educational and research programs.

I wish to make a brief comment on the changes in structure. When it was revealed in the Press last year that there was to be a change to the War Memorial and to its facade, I raised a number of questions in the Senate and dealt with the matter on the adjournment on a number of occasions. I made two visits to the War Memorial and I and others were dismayed that the view of the Hall of Memories was to be obscured. On one of my visits there were present representatives from the National Capital Development Commission with their plans. I asked why they could not achieve what they had to achieve for the purpose of the convenience and comfort of visitors without changing the exterior of the building, and I was simply told: 'That is not possible'. I was not told why. Therefore, I welcomed the decision later in the year not to proceed with that change to the War Memorial. It was and is possible to make the changes necessary for the comfort and convenience of visitors. It was not necessary to change the exterior of the War Memorial. It is a warning to us all that when a structure as important as that building is to be tampered with by the experts we should closely examine their claims of necessity. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

One of the more difficult debates that the Parliament had to face in the last five or seven years was the furore over the use of recombinant DNA technology in Australia, the uses to which hybrid DNA could be put, and the concern by some members of the community that there was danger in the technique. I thought at the time that some of the criticism was reasonable and well-founded, some hysterical and unreasonable. Some people sought to ban the introduction of recombinant DNA technology. That is simply not possible. It is now with us and gives the promise of considerable advantage to the community by way of the production of specialised organisms with particular biological properties. As yet the technology is only being developed.

The development of this Recombinant DNA Monitoring Committee to oversight the operation of this technology in Australia has been positive and its first report is impressive. I congratulate the Committee on the way it has gone about its work and draw to the attention of the Senate the fact that the Committee has already detected and dealt with at least one breach of the guidelines it laid down for the application of this technology in Australia. I draw particular attention to the fact that this technology, which was feared by many and which many people did not understand, is being carried out extensively in Australia. Bass Strait Freight Adjustment Trust Fund Bill 1984

The purpose of the Bill is to establish a trust fund for the purpose of making payments to refiners of crude oil. Related Bills, the Bass Strait Freight Adjustment Levy Bill 1984 and the Bass Strait Freight Adjustment Levy Collection Bill 1984, provide for the imposition of an additional levy on Bass Strait crude oil and for the collection of the levy.

This package of Bills will impose an additional levy of $1.26 a kilolitre (20c a barrel) on all crude oil produced from Bass Strait. After rebates to the producers for exports and their producers' entitlement crude oil, the proceeds of the levy will be redistributed to refiners in a way that reflects the freight costs incurred in transporting Bass Strait crude oil from Westernport to each refinery.

The Bill, and the related Bills, will not change the price of Bass Strait crude oil to the Australian community. Although the individual cost structure of each refiner will be affected by these measures, the overall cost to the industry will remain unchanged.

Prior to the introduction of the Crude Oil Absorption Scheme in September 1970, lengthy discussions were held with the oil industry concerning details of its operation. The Government of the day recognised that there would be some extra cost involved in using Bass Strait crude oil, because of its movement to the various refineries, and it expressed the wish at the time to see this extra cost borne equitably between refiners. All companies undertook to examine the problem with the objective of finding a solution. In the event no solution was found and , although the matter has been examined a number of times in the intervening years, the problem has remained.

Following further representations from some refiners in 1983, the matter was discussed at a meeting between the Minister for Resources and Energy and refiners in July 1983. At that meeting, the refiners were again asked to seek a solution acceptable to the industry. Again the industry was unable to agree and therefore, as was foreshadowed at the meeting with the industry, the Government has decided to take steps to resolve this matter.

The indigenous Crude Oil Absorption Policy imposes a collective obligation on marketers of petroleum products in Australia to absorb indigenous crude oil and to arrange for its refining within Australia. Each company's share of the indigenous crude oil available is calculated on the basis of its share of sales in Australia of certain specified petroleum products.

It is not a requirement that each marketer should refine its share of crude in its own refinery-the policy is designed to ensure that freight movements are minimised. For all producing areas, with the single exception of the Bass Strait fields, all production can be absorbed at the nearest refinery.

The import parity pricing arrangements value indigenous crude oil at the notional cost of landing Arabian light crude oil at the refinery port nearest to the producing field. In the case of Bass Strait crude oil the nearest refinery is at Westernport, Victoria. Because that refinery cannot absorb the entire production, an adjustment is made to the import parity price which reflects the notional cost of transporting the overflow first to the other Victorian refineries at Altona and Geelong and then to refineries in Sydney and Brisbane. This calculation results in a reduction of 36c a barrel in the price of Bass Strait crude oil to all refiners, although the actual costs incurred in moving Bass Strait crude from Westernport to the various refineries range from zero at Westernport to around 96c a barrel at Brisbane.

The arrangements proposed in this and the related Bills recognise this inequity by proposing a redistribution of 20c a barrel of the coastal freight adjustment component of the import parity price for Bass Strait crude oil among all refiners to reflect differences in the cost of transporting crude oil from Westernport.

In deciding to redistribute 20c rather than the full 36c, the Government has recognised the investment made by the Melbourne refiners in pipelines to minimise their cost of moving crude oil and the additional costs they face in the coastal shipping of some petroleum products.

The levy of $1.26 per kilolitre (20c a barrel) will be imposed on production of all crude oil from Bass Strait. This will be collected by the Bureau of Customs. Funds equivalent to the proceeds of the levy will be appropriated from consolidated revenue to a trust account to be administered by the Department of Resources and Energy. The full amount of the levy will be reimbursed to the producers for any crude oil produced that is not included in the allocation scheme. The balance of the funds will be redistributed among the refiners on the basis of movements of crude oil over the most recent 30 months and the assessed costs of transport to each refinery. Determination of distributions from the trust fund will be made on 1 January and 1 July each year but the first determination will be made immediately upon proclamation of this and the related legislation and will apply from 1 January 1984.

For coastal shipping movements, the freight rates to be applied in making determinations will be the published average freight rate assessment (AFRA) and worldscale rates for large range tankers up to 80,000 tonnes (LR1), and insurance and loss will be based on the standard allowed of 0.6 per cent presently included in the import parity price calculations. In the case of pipeline transfers, the actual pipeline costs will be used.
Each refiner's share of the freight equalisation fund will be calculated by the formula described in clause 9 of the Bill.

The proposals in this and the related Bills represent a compromise between the views put to the Government in recent months by the Sydney and Brisbane based refiners and those of the Melbourne based refiners. The proposals are designed to resolve an unsatisfactory situation that has been a source of concern in the petroleum industry for a number of years.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Bass Strait Freight Adjustment Levy Bill 1984

This Bill proposes to introduce a levy on crude oil produced from offshore areas in Bass Strait. The Bill is part of a package of measures to give effect to the Government's decision to introduce a scheme to compensate refiners of Bass Strait crude oil for costs incurred in moving that crude oil to the various refineries.
Details of the scheme are outlined in the second reading speech relating to the Bass Strait Freight Adjustment Trust Fund Bill 1984.
This Bill provides for the imposition of a freight adjustment levy of $1.26 a kilolitre on the producers for crude oil produced in Bass Strait.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Bass Strait Freight Adjustment Levy Collection Bill 1984

This Bill is the third of a package of Bills prepared to give effect to the Government's decision to introduce a scheme to compensate refiners of crude oil for costs incurred in moving that crude to the various refineries.

Details of the scheme are outlined in the second reading speech on the Bass Strait Freight Adjustment Trust Fund Bill 1984. This Bill provides the machinery necessary for the collection of the Adjustment Levy.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
