DEBATE.TITLE: COMPANIES AND SECURITIES LEGISLATION (MISCELLANEOUS AMENDMENTS) BILL (No. 1) 1984

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 28 March, on motion by Senator Gareth Evans:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: — The Companies and Securities Legislation (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill (No. 1) which was introduced into the Senate last week and which, as far as I am aware, was not the subject of any earlier public exposure, as often occurs with legislation in this field, contains a number of amendments to the companies and securities legislation scheme. The major provisions of this Bill are: It defines and allows for registration of persons participating in time sharing arrangements; it alters the law controlling the registration of charges to overcome some specific problems; and it contains a number of amendments which are required consequent upon the deregulation of the stock exchanges as from 1 April this year. Of course, in accordance with the co-operative scheme the Bill was quite recently approved by the Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not propose to deal in the second reading debate with the amendments relating to time sharing and registration of charges. Suffice it to say that the amendments in relation to time sharing introduce legislative arrangements in relation to time sharing which is a growing industry and presents new legal problems which, I think, had been to a large extent overcome under existing law. As a result of the recent decision it was thought necessary to make the amendments which are contained in the legislation. Some difficulties with these amendments have been perceived by those in the industry and they have been in touch with me. At this stage all I say is that there is very considerable concern that amendments to matters of this kind should proceed at such a pace through the Parliament without those in the industry having time adequately to consider them and to make representations to senators and members.

The major purpose of this legislation, certainly one of the greatest importance , is to change the legislation with respect to stock exchanges. This is an extremely important development in the organisation, membership and conduct of stock exchanges and members of stock exchanges in this country. The changes are very much in line with what is happening in the stock exchange at least in the City of London. These changes are very much on the side of greater competition, greater efficiency and, I hope, better advice and service for investors in the future.

There has been a great deal of discussion about these changes in the Press in recent days. There are various concerns about just what the impact of the changes will be, but everybody agrees that they are major. Certainly they ought to result in the long term, if not immediately in the short term, in a better service for investors. In brief the changes allow: The opening up of negotiated rates; 50 per cent outside ownership of broking firms; the incorporation of broking firms; members to become members of more than one exchange; and non- broker directors of member corporations. Thus just a brief summary of the major features of the new arrangements emphasises the very great changes and the importance of them.

Again, it is a pity that this legislation is being discussed after the actual amendments have been made to the stock exchange rules and the adapting of the Act. It did not have to come into effect before 1 April, but I think it would have been better if the legislation had been available for public discussion, certainly for discussion in this chamber, before 1 April when the changes came into effect. We come back to the same problem we discussed last time with amendments to the scheme; namely, that all this is done through Federal and State officials, through the ministerial council administering the scheme, and Parliament is just presented with a like it or lump it solution. I had some comment to make about that some months ago when last year we discussed the major Bill dealing with this subject. I do not propose to repeat those comments. Perhaps in this case there are particular reasons why it is necessary for this legislation to go through in this way. I indicate that in future the Opposition will not simply rubber stamp legislation of this kind. Certainly we will require proper time in this Parliament to debate the legislation; if we do not like the legislation we will propose that the matter be taken back to the Ministerial Council. We will not simply rubber stamp what that Council decides.

The changes in this legislation, however, have a long history. It is an interesting and important story and one which I believe was brought about as a result of the previous Liberal-National Party Government allowing the legislation to proceed. It was its policy that the Trade Practices Commission should be able to retain its authority in this area, despite the fact that there was a great deal of suport, certainly in some sections of the securities industry, for the view that this power of the Trade Practices Commission should be removed and that the mater should be left solely to the National Companies and Securities Commission. The history of this matter goes back in fact to shortly after the introduction of the Trade Practices Act when the stock exchanges were put on notice that their restrictive trade practices relating to the fixing of brokerage rates and restrictions to membership of exchanges probably contravened the Trade Practices Act. An interim authorisation was obtained for those practices, but it was quite clear that at some stage or other something would have to be done about them.

The matter was brought to a head in July 1981 by a group of merchant bankers seeking by mandamus proceedings against the Trade Practices Commission to compel the Commission to examine the rules and articles of association. The resultant case in fact was settled on an undertaking being given by the Commission to carry out such an examination, and almost immediately that examination began. The Trade Practices Commission issued interim findings and proposals in relation to those matters in about the middle of 1982, as a result of which a considerable amount of discussion took place-I can remember it myself-in the Ministerial Council about whether this procedure ought to be allowed to continue or whether this scheme should be amended in such a way that that power once again was taken away from the Trade Practices Commission and handed over to the National Companies and Securities Commission. However, that did not eventuate. The powers given to the Trade Practices Commission were permitted to take effect and negotiations were entered into. As I recall, submissions were made by the Ministerial Council or by the National Companies and Securities Commission to the Trade Practices Commission about the matter.

The upshot was that in September 1982 the Trade Practices Commission issued its final decision, under which it refused authorisation of the existing rules but granted an interim authorisation for 18 months to enable amendments to be made. Those amendments have now been make, taking effect as from 1 April this year. In March this year the Trade Practices Commission granted an interim authorisation for those new draft rules and articles of association to which I have referred. An interesting development was that the interim authorisation allowed negotiated rates for all transactions over $100,000 but did not require the rates to be changed for those transactions under $100,000 for another 12 months. As I understand the position, certainly the stock exchanges in Melbourne and Sydney decided to permit the negotiation of rates in all transactions as from 1 April. So those stock exchanges have gone a step further than they were required to go. That is an interesting example of how changes in this area are moving at a greater pace than people thought would occur.

As I said, the Ministerial Council has to approve the new rules. I understand that it has not yet done so. Perhaps the Attorney-General in his reply will give the Senate some indication of what stage the Ministerial Council has reached in its consideration of the matter. The present opening up of stock exchanges is being referred to as deregulation. It is interesting to note, however, that such deregulation had been imposed by the stock exchanges themselves under their restrictive practices; it was not done by government fiat. For want of a better word, it is being called deregulation.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is self-deregulation.

—I thank Senator Jack Evans. It is self-deregulation. That is a very good point. It is only part of the package. Quite a number of items in the package still have to be resolved, particularly those concerned with conflicts of interest. There is obviously a concern, with the incorporation of stockbroking firms, about a conflict of interest between the shareholders- directors of the firm and the business of the client. Various matters concerned with that aspect have to be discussed. It is important that they be resolved as soon as possible. Concern about that matter is perhaps not most immediate because it will be a few weeks yet before any corporate members are licensed to trade. However, that is clearly a fairly urgent problem that needs to be addressed and resolved.

SPEECH.PARA: I understand that the matter of whether higher entry fees should be paid for corporate membership of a stock exchange has yet to be decided. Apparently no decision has yet been made on the question of crossing rules. A matter that I think should have been addressed at an earlier stage concerns fidelity funds. The new rules will enable a broker to be a member of more than one stock exchange. That raises the question whether the present approach in relation to fidelity funds is the appropriate one. Fidelity fund regulations at present operate on the basis of a broker being a member of only one exchange, and each exchange has its own fidelity fund. Discussion is taking place about whether there should be a national fidelity fund. That important aspect of the matter, as I said, has not yet been resolved. All these matters have been in the pipeline for 18 months now. It was known that major changes were to take effect as from 1 April-although perhaps not as many as have taken place-and that other aspects were under consideration. It seems a pity that further advances have not been made towards resolving those other matters in the package that require urgent decision.

I come back to the point I dealt with earlier, namely, that many matters that should have been dealt with remain unresolved. The legislation dealing with this most important area should have been debated at an earlier stage so that the views of members of this Parliament could be obtained. A good deal of concern has been expressed in the financial industry about what attitude the Foreign Investment Review Board will take to the matter of overseas brokerage firms gaining membership of Australian stock exchanges. Both local and overseas organisations want to know now, at the inception of the scheme, whether the Government intends to allow overseas firms to participate in these new, more open stock exchanges in Australia.

The Opposition welcomes these proposed changes and supports the measure. As I said, they are in line with the Opposition's policy of greater competition, greater efficiency in industry and more services being available to those participating in and benefiting from an industry, which in this case is the securities industry. In fact, the proposed changes follow the policies pursued quite firmly and definitely by the Opposition when in government. I have indicated the history of this matter. The Opposition hopes that the matters which are still outstanding, important as many of them are, will be not only urgently addressed but also resolved in the near future so that we can look forward, as a result of these changes, to greater efficiency in our stock exchanges.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support what has been said by the former Attorney-General, Senator Durack. I refer to the point he made that most of the matters contained in the proposed amendment to the Companies and Securities Legislation (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill (No. 1) have been in the pipeline for 18 months or so. That is not said as a reflection in any way upon the present Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans). I am certainly not raising it in that sense; rather I am making a point. The point is that progress in this area moves at an inordinately slow pace. Whilst I believe the use of co- operative federalism as an approach to overcoming a problem involving a very rapidly changing and very fast moving industry can be of considerable benefit in some areas of legislative operation, it is totally unsuited to companies and securities legislation. This has been one of the reasons for the considerable difficulties which have been experienced by the National Companies and Securities Commission.

SPEECH.PARA: The National Companies and Securities Commission is made up of extremely competent senior staff. I know that the commissioners are extremely competent people who have the experience, the capacity and the good will to make the system work. Yet many people believe that to date the Commission has not succeeded, that it has not been able to notch up many successes in being able to clarify, expedite and reduce the cost of, the regulatory aspects of the conduct of business through the corporate state and transactions in relation to securities associated with corporations. I believe this to be a matter of some very considerable concern. This Parliament should give further consideration to the action to be taken which might enhance the role of the National Companies and Securities Commission and thereby expedite the process by which results can be achieved.

I know that my saying that has not taken the Attorney-General by surprise, but I believe it is important to say, and to repeat, that changes are taking place. As I think my colleague Senator Durack said, one of the major changes is a change in relation to a form of self-regulation, self-protection, in which the stock exchanges had engaged, regarding their refusal to adopt negotiated rates. This system has applied in the United States for quite some time and is generally regarded there as being beneficial to the operation of the industry.

In early October last year when I was in London I attended a securities function. At that time members who were attending that function were in the middle of their discussion leading up to the vote which was to be made a few days later on changes to be made in relation to regulation in the city of London regarding brokerage and other matters. This caused a sudden spate of activity in Australia among the brokers and led to the changes to which Senator Durack referred, which are in the nature of self-deregulation. I think one of the very welcome aspects is that some people have said and made quite clear they propose to go all out for the big business. Presumably they will fix their rates and services according to those which are required by the big clients.

There is a variety of requirements of people associated with investment through the stock exchanges in Australia. Very often people tend to forget the difference between the very large institutions, which do their own research and make up their own mind as to what investment they regard as best suiting their purpose, and the smaller institutions. The larger institutions want from stockbrokers on the floor of the stock exchange professional expertise in relation to the transactions but not in relation to research and advice. There are other and smaller institutions which do not have and have not had the volume of investment funds which would enable them to have that sort of degree of expertise available to them unless brokers, for an appropriate charge, provided research services and advice to investors of, shall I say, the more medium category who wish to be able to receive expert, well-researched and in-depth analysis of the potential of various types of investment through the stock exchanges.

Then there are the small investors, some of whom invest through investments available through unit trusts and other forms of combined investment. Those trusts do their own type of research and can give advice to the smaller client. Very often people who invest in a small way would like to invest in their own employer's company. Such people, who have their own ideas, do their own research and form their own hunches, find it burdensome to have a minimum fee charged by a broker for the transaction which they regard as a relatively simple matter.

When I was involved with a Senate inquiry in relation to this matter I received a letter from a Melbourne school teacher who said that he wished to provide for his retirement and had decided that, in his opinion, the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd was the form of investment which would best suit his requirements for long term stability and capital gain. He intended to invest regularly every month, whatever income he obtained from the shares which he already had in BHP, together with his savings, in the purchase of further shares in BHP. He pointed out to me what was in effect a tax imposed on that sort of transaction by a relatively small investor. The investor had to pay duty and the minimum fee charged by the stockbroker.

One of the developments that have come about now means that the type of person who knows what he or she wants and who wants the transaction carried out in the simplest way can take advantage of the real depth of opportunity for shares in companies listed on some of the major stock exchanges. Such transactions can take place at the shop front, over the counter as it were, rather than by the more complex means. Modern communications mean that it is possible simply to call up the board at either the Melbourne Stock Exchange or the Sydney Stock Exchange and by computer linkage be able to check the price so that the person can be informed by telephone, can make an instant decision and carry out the transaction in an extremely simple way.

When Sir Cecil Looker was the President of the Australian Associated Stock Exchanges and the Melbourne Stock Exchange, he brought Mr Gordon Gilmour from Canada to advise us about a new system for a scrip bank and a far more efficient system of transactions in relation to securities in Australia. Mr Gilmour, from whom I received a letter last Christmas, has gone back to Canada much the wiser but without very great enthusiasm for the prospects of change in Australia. He battled away. The scrip bank has been introduced in such countries as South Africa and in various other parts of the world. But Australia is still struggling to streamline its procedures.

I do not think that the co-operative federalism approach that we are still continuing to adopt, in relation to what is undoubtedly now a Commonwealth area of responsibility, will enable the sorts of changes to which I have briefly referred to take place with reasonable expedition. I am not suggesting that people are deliberately holding up the process, but it is one which is inherently slow and inherently unlikely to be able to ensure that change can be made as and when necessary. The process has been extremely unfair to the members who have taken the responsibility of conducting the affairs of the National Companies and Securities Commission. I wish that Commission well.

I take the opportunity to say that I do not believe that the idea which is sometimes floated in Australia, that we should adopt the city panel approach from the City of London, has any validity in Australia. There is a vast difference between Australia and the extremely close-knit operation in the City of London, one of the major financial centres, if not the major financial centre , of the world. It is dominated by the Bank of England and the Bank of England's capacity, together with the Board of Trade and the new Department of Industry and Trade in the United Kingdom, which have tremendous power in one city area, to be able to manage and regulate particularly takeovers and mergers. Australia has an entirely different and an entirely disparate situation, one which can be brought closer together and which will, with the advent of greater technological application of communications systems, be brought closer together. But the rate of change is not sufficient to warrant even the slightest moment of consideration of the application, in relation to the question of takeovers and mergers, of the British approach of a takeover panel. There is no way that that can be suitable to this country at this country's stage of development. I hope that we do not hear any more of that sort of attack on the National Companies and Securities Commission but rather some greater support for that Commission to be able to fulfil that task effectively and expeditiously.

It is one of the areas in which there has been the greatest amount of complaint in the industry and from those associated with the industry. The mergers and takeovers area is one field with over-regulation and confusion rather than one in which it is possible to have some reasonably clear rules which enable desirable practices to take place expeditiously and efficiently, and undesirable practices to be banned.

There is no doubt that the securities industry area is one in which, human nature being what it is, if one permits undesirable practices to take place, they will take place on the part of a percentage of the people involved. Fortunately, it is a small percentage but, as a casino, a race track and any other area of gambling and the making of a fast buck attracts the attention of the fast buck makers, so too can the stock exchanges and the securities industry attract the attention of the fast buck makers if their regulations are so sloppy , inefficient or cumbersome that they are not able to act expeditiously.

Previously in this chamber I have outlined numerous shortcomings that exist at the moment in the present system, and I will not go through those again. I welcome the legislation. My colleague Senator Durack has made specific comment about parts of it and I understand my colleague Senator Hill is to make comments on other aspects of it. I have made those general comments because they need to be made from time to time, particularly in relation to the current debate as to whether there ought to be a more effective role for the National Companies and Securities Commission in relation to takeovers and mergers or whether we ought to consider some sort of Australian adaptation of the city takeover panel. The city takeover panel will not work in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you think the time might be right for consideration by a Senate committee of the whole co-operative scheme?

—Yes, I have believed ever since this legislation was first mooted that a Senate committee should be set up to keep an eye on this scheme. It could be a contact point, a legislative focal point, for the National Companies and Securities Commission and other associated review bodies, such as in regard to accountancy and company law, to be able to have some associations and platform with and some input into the parliamentary system. I certainly believe that the time is well and truly right for that to happen. Some considerable advantage can come to Australia's economic development and to the operation of our capitalist system by the working efficiency overall of the industry. A Senate committee could assist in that.

SPEECH.PARA: In conclusion I wish to say that, in case there is some doubt about my attitude towards regulation-some people seem to think that I have been an advocate of regulation for the securities industry-my chief complaint always was that there were 14 pieces of legislation with which industry, the larger corporate activities of Australia on an Australia-wide basis, had to combat and that what we needed was a unified approach, one which cut out the red tape, cut out much of the delay, was more cost efficient, more time efficient and more effective in achieving the objective of a fair, open, efficient and free operating market system in Australia. I have always believed that what is needed is a regulatory framework with the freedom to operate under some reasonably clear rules but with a stick behind it to make sure that it is working efficiently. I thank the Senate for the opportunity to make these comments. I indicated that, like my colleague Senator Durack, I am glad to support the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a pleasure in this debate to follow the two constructive and informative speeches from my colleagues the shadow Attorney-General Senator Durack and Senator Peter Rae. It is a pity that there seems to be little interest in the subject matter from the Government benches. I simply touch upon the last point that was made by Senator Rae when he spoke of the frustrations and problems of a securities industry which had to exist under 14 separate pieces of legislation. I remind the Senate that that industry now has to exist under the Companies Code, the Companies (Fees) Act 1981, the Companies Regulations, the State Variations to Companies Regulations, the Companies (Fees) Regulations, the Companies (Acquisition of Shares) Code, the Companies (Acquisition of Shares) Amendment Act (No. 2) 1981, the Companies ( Acquisition of Shares-Fees) Act 1980, the Companies (Acquisition of Shares) Regulations, the Companies (Acquisition of Shares-Fees) Regulations, the National Companies and Securities Commission Act of 1979, the National Companies and Securities Commission Regulations, the National Companies and Securities Commission (State Provisions) Acts, the Securities Industry Code, the Securities Industry Regulations, the State Variations to the Securities Industry Regulations, the Securities Industry (Fees) Regulations, the Companies and Securities (Interpretation and Miscellaneous Provisions) Act of 1980, the State Interpretation and Miscellaneous Provisions Codes, the Companies (Transitional Provisions) Act of 1981, the Companies (Transitional Provisions) Regulations, the Companies (Application of Laws) Acts, the Companies (Application of Laws- Transitional Provisions) Regulations 1982 and the Crown Debts (Priority) Act 1981. I remind the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) of the further companies legislation that we passed in November of last year.

SPEECH.PARA: Today we have a further piece of legislation, the Companies and Securities Legislation (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill (No. 1) 1984. I notice that it is optimistically labelled No. 1. I presume that indicates that we can expect more in the course of this year. If Senator Peter Rae was looking for some consolidation and simplification of the new system, it is obvious that that has not come about.

I simply want to make a few comments to voice my continuing concern as to the operation of the co-operative scheme and the quality of the Bills that we are receiving from the Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities. A Bill that we debated in the Senate on 16 November 1983 contained many provisions that were ambiguous and contradictory. It contained a number of provisions that were of doubtful merit. On that occasion I raised many separate questions. I understood that the Minister could not reasonably be expected to answer those questions on the run. However, I was given an undertaking that the matters I raised would be looked at and considered and that I would be advised of the outcome of that consideration in due course. Much in line with general progress of matters in this area, I have not yet received that reply although in excess of four months have already passed. It is not unreasonable of me to think that that is unsatisfactory. I appreciate the problem that the Minister has because I am not sure who would actually give me the answers. Presumably he would not see it as his responsibility; he would refer it to the Ministerial Council. This is just another facet of this unsatisfactory scheme for corporate law and securities which we presently have in this country.

I wanted to move amendments to the legislation we dealt with last November. No one was sure as to whether that was possible and if, in fact, the Senate did pass amendments, what would be the effect of those amendments. This is a problem that we are forced to address again today in that by passing this Bill we also alter a series of State laws. If the legislation were altered we would, in effect, be altering something that has already been agreed to by State Ministers . Of course, we bear in mind that in this most unusual procedure there are no opportunities for the State parliaments concerned to debate the legislation. So we have the frustrating position that we are presented with Bills of this nature and we are even unsure that we have the power to amend them. Certainly, we were warned against attempting to amend them because of the complications that would follow. That, I would respectfully suggest, reduces the Federal Parliament's role in this process to little short of a farce. To use the words of one of the previous speakers in this debate, it reduces the role of this Parliament to simply that of a rubber stamp. One might argue that that is what happens in any event in the other place. But we in the Senate believe that we have a responsibility to consider the detail of Bills that appear before us and to take such action in relation to those Bills as appears appropriate. But in relation to the unique pieces of proposed legislation under the co-operative scheme we are told that in fact we cannot do that.

I think the whole sham which is this debate is made just so apparent from the fact that the deregulation, if I might call it that, of stock exchanges is to commence, as previous speakers said, from 1 April 1984. Of course, that day has already passed. Here we are now in the Senate being presented with a Bill that deals with the necessary changes to the Securities Industry Act 1980. What if we do not agree with those changes? Everything is in train. As I indicated, our role is simply being reduced to that of a rubber stamp.

As previous speakers have mentioned, but it is worth stating again, the Trade Practices Commission put down its final report in September 1982. One must ask where the Bill has been in the meantime? Presumably it has been somewhere with the Ministerial Council. Furthermore, even though we now have the Bill after the deregulated scheme has come into effect, we are told-and this is obvious from the contents of the Minister's second reading speech-that this is not all that is going to be necessary. The Minister acknowledges that we are getting just a small piece on this occasion and that in the months ahead the Ministerial Council is 'likely', to use the Minister's word, to look at further matters. Quite helpfully, the Minister throws in a few that are apparent to him. There are others that would be apparent to anyone with experience in this area who gave the matter consideration. He mentioned the question that is going to arise as to whether national fidelity bonds will become more appropriate in cases of corporate membership. He also mentioned the question of the conflict of interest arising from the inevitable entry of financial institutions into the stockbroking industry, and that is clearly a question with which we should be concerning ourselves.

My colleagues and I indicate our concern that it has taken some 18 months to get these changes to the securities legislation in order. Now, in a very unsatisfactory way, we are presented with a Bill which deals with a very small part of that package and are simply told that the Ministerial Council is likely to give further consideration to the other obvious matters in due course. I do not regard that as a satisfactory state of affairs. There is no better example that I can find of the web of intertwined legislation and regulation, the sheer mass of paper and the consequent difficulty and frustration of all those who have to live and work under this scheme, than in the amendments that are put before us today in relation to the registration of legal and equitable charges. It seems to me to be just a classical example of where we have gone in this field. Section 200 of the Companies Act describes the charges required to be registered. That is okay; it is a provision of long standing in corporate law. The Minister says in his second reading speech that it is necessary to clarify what securities come within section 200 (1) (h). We are given no further information as to why it is necessary to clarify this paragraph. The Minister proposes the insertion of new sub-sections after section 200 (4). Proposed new sub-section (4A) reads:
The reference in paragraph (1) (h) to a lien or charge on a crop, a lien or charge on wool or a stock mortgage includes a reference to a security (however described) that is registrable under-
(a) a provision that is a relevant provision for the purposes of this sub- section;
I really do not know what that means. In my case it simply has the effect of confusing me further.

TALK.START.PARA: —Read the explanatory memorandum.
—I have read the explanatory memorandum. Perhaps in due course the Minister will make a better attempt of explaining to the Senate how that is going to clarify rather than further confuse the issue.

SPEECH.PARA: Section 211 is the provision that avoids the need for double registration. The Minister says that there are doubts as to whether section 211 satisfactorily removes the obligation to comply with the relevant provisions of the instruments or bills of sale Acts of a State. The Government is attempting a new provision to cover the relationship with the code and the Australian Capital Territory Instruments Ordinance 1933. When that is read those concerned will have to substitute the appropriate State Acts, but the State Acts, the instruments Acts and the bills of sale Acts all vary. Therefore, as the Minister says, there is need for translator regulations in each State varying according to the differing approaches of States in their bills of sale and instruments legislation. So the process continues with the mass of paper forever building up, and the challenge to those who must interpret these provisions and work within and under them becoming more and more impossible. That is to say nothing of the tortuous drafting of proposed section 211.

TALK.START.PARA: —Would you prefer to leave the matter in doubt and not have the redrafting?

—I would not prefer the matter to be left in doubt. I would prefer it to be put in a way in which it was not in doubt. In passing this Bill, the Parliament will bind the States without the State parliaments having an opportunity to consider these matters. Therefore, honourable senators have a considerable responsibility which I feel they are not discharging.

SPEECH.PARA: I said of the last Bill on this topic in November that it should have been considered by the Senate committee system. I listened with interest to the exchange between the Attorney-General and Senator Peter Rae on the way in which a Senate select committee could look at the whole operation of a co-operative scheme. I also would applaud such a step. I believe that the procedures that the Senate is now accepting are simply not good enough. I am embarrassed as I believe the Minister should be. If this so-called co-operative scheme is to continue, let us at least develop a system whereby the Senate can properly discharge its function in relation to these Bills.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I welcome the support expressed for the Companies and Securities Legislation (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill (No. 1), tempered on occasion as it may have been by the odd criticism of particular aspects. Nevertheless, there is support for the legislation, and that is appreciated, especially relating to the central part of the Bill which responds to the situation created by the opening up of the stockbroking closed shop following the original Trade Practices Commission determination in 1982 and the expiry of the interim authorisation in relation to brokerage rates on the first of this month.

SPEECH.PARA: There has been criticism about the rush to legislate intermingled, it must be said, by criticism of the slowness of the legislative process to respond to stimuli that arise in this complex area of the law. But to the extent that criticism is made of the failure to expose the Bill to comment earlier than the 10 days or so as has been the case on this occasion, it fails to appreciate the special circumstances of this legislation. Although it is the case that the original TPC determination was made in 1982, and although it has been clear since last July that the TPC approach to this would prevail and that the Commonwealth would not take the view that stock exchanges deserve a continuing immunity from the operation of trade practices legislation, it has only been since January this year-three months ago-that the rules of the stock exchanges have been changed. Indeed, the last set of rules has been sorted out only now. As a practical matter it was not possible to draft this legislation, which is designed to accommodate the new structures within the stock exchanges and the firms that comprise them, until such time as the structure of those rules was finally determined.

There is a need for the legislation to be in place and on the statute books by the time that the first corporate member of the stock exchange is admitted. That process may be only three or four weeks away now that that corporate membership is possible, following the expiry of the interim authorisation on 1 April and the opening of the exchanges in the way with which we are all familiar. That is the reason for the rush on that aspect of the legislation.

As for the time sharing arrangements, again the rush is simply to close a loophole that became very visible when the Brentwood Village case arose last year and made it necessary to get the legislative fences quickly into place to ensure that the existing provisions of the Bill could not be sidestepped in a manifestly unintended way. Senator Durack foreshadowed criticisms of the particular content of the time sharing provisions of the present legislation. I do not believe those criticisms have substance, but perhaps it would be better to tackle that point in the Committee stage.

As for the matter of charges, the third major subject area of the Bill, perhaps there is not the same degree of urgency to clarify the law which I believe this legislation does. But it is the case, and has been the case, that there has been a considerable degree of uncertainty as to whether the charges, be they related to wool liens and the various charges provided for in the Bill, were legally effective simply by virtue of being registered under the Companies Act. The matter in issue was whether simultaneous or dual registration was necessary under a miscellany of bits and pieces of State and Territory legislation. What is involved here is essentially the enactment of avoidance of doubt provisions to ensure that charges given over property which have been assumed to be valid are in fact valid. When these questions arise the commercial community always urges the Government to move quickly to avoid doubt. That is what the Government has sought to do through the Ministerial Council apparatus on this occasion.

I believe that the contribution made by Senator Hill to this part of the debate drawing attention to the complexity of these legislative provisions fell short of the standard reached by his usual contributions in this place. Difficult and complex as this commercial legislation is, of course, it will be the case that any given part of any given section as proposed will be largely unintelligible not least when uttered out of context in a debate such as this. I do not believe anything follows from the complexity to which Senator Hill drew attention.

I was asked by Senator Durack what was happening to the implications of the Trade Practices Act in regard to the stock exchanges. I was asked by him to comment or to give such further information as I could in relation to the proposed new stock exchange articles and business rules permitting corporate membership of the exchanges and the unfixing of certain brokerage rates. So far as the draft rules relating to brokerage are concerned, the draft rules abolishing the fixed brokerage rate were granted interim authorisation by the TPC on 10 February 1984 for the period 1 April 1984 to 1 October 1985. We understand that the Melbourne and Sydney exchanges adopted these rules last week , on 29 March, and that the other exchanges adopted them on 30 March. The rules here are non-controversial and the National Companies and Securities Commission is in the process of recommending to Ministers not to disallow them. I do not anticipate any problem in regard to their status.

As to the draft articles relating to natural persons membership and corporate membership, the TPC granted interim authorisation to these draft articles on 6 March 1984. The exchanges were holding meetings last week to approve the new articles, and I understand they have in fact been approved. They will be lodged, if that has not already happened, with the NCSC this week when the statutory disallowance period of 28 days will start to run. It is premature at this stage to say whether there will be any difficulty in relation to those rules. If there is, I suspect it will be only at the margin.

The carrying on of business and principal trading rules become available to the Government only during last week. They deal with a number of controversial matters, particularly those related to conflicts of interest. It is the case that the exchanges have not adopted a uniform approach to these issues so there may well be a degree of extra controversy and delay associated with the bringing of those rules into force and effect. I am not sure whether there is anything else that Senator Durack wanted to know about the current state of play but if there is I will be happy to try to accommodate him in the Committee stage.

It remains only to say a word or two more generally about the operation of the companies and securities legislation and the present joint Commonwealth-State co -operative scheme. I note the concerns that were expressed by Senator Hill about the complexity of the scheme and I note the contributions he has made, particularly in the course of a very long and detailed speech in the latter part of last year in the last round of amending legislation designed to draw attention to some of the perceived deficiencies in the existing legislation. I am sorry that he has not had a detailed response from me yet as I promised to give him by way of comment on the points he made about the operation of that legislation. The answer basically is that he raised so many points of such complexity that it is only very recently, I am told by my Department, that the draft reply has, in fact, been prepared. Indeed, the Department's comments for my attention have been prepared in the context of a larger exercise designed to pull together all the criticisms that have been made of the current legislation with a view to attention in the next round of remedial legislation which will be considered by the ministerial council meeting in May. It was not originally anticipated that I would respond in detail to Senator Hill before the ministerial council had an opportunity to meet and consider these matters but if he presses the point I am happy to give him such interim response as I can before then.

The remaining general point relates to the matters raised by Senator Peter Rae. I very much welcome the support that was given by him to the National Companies and Securities Commission, which has been something of an embattled warrior in this area since the date of its inception. I also particularly welcome the very obvious support he gave to the need for effective legislation in this respect in the whole area. It has been a familiar theme for both of us in recent years. I think Senator Rae and I are both very well aware of the deficiencies of the present system although Senator Rae has become a little more circumspect about articulating the weaknesses of the co-operative scheme as such since he assumed his place on the front bench of the Opposition. Nonetheless, I think that most of the deficiencies he perceives in the present system and a good many of the deficiencies that Senator Hill perceives could much better be accommodated in the context not of the continued operation of this Heath Robinson co-operative scheme but rather in the context of unilateral Commonwealth companies and securities legislation.

The Commonwealth has made its position clear. It will not charge in to endeavour to overturn the existing co-operative scheme so long as it continues to operate reasonably satisfactorily and in the interests of the Australian commercial community. But it has become increasingly obvious to me after some time scrutinising the system from the outside and now with a year or more's experience of scrutinising it from the inside that it is an almost wholly unsatisfactory way of responding to the very real needs of the Australian business community. I believe, as I indicated by way of interjection to Senator Rae, that the time has probably come for a really detailed reconsideration of the whole future of the Commonwealth's attitude to the co-operative scheme. I suspect that one of the most useful ways of doing this and preserving a bipartisan flavour in the process may well be to give a Senate committee-maybe one specially constituted for the purpose, maybe the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs, or maybe some other committee-a reference to look at the way in which the aims of the co-operative companies and securities scheme have been realised or not realised as the case may be; the way in which, perhaps, the range of Commonwealth legislative powers might be utilised to underpin a single national scheme, not involving co-operative relationships of this kind, which have not worked awfully well; and the extent to which a national scheme, enacted by the Parliament, might or should encompass the matters currently covered by the legislation enacted under the co-operative companies and securities scheme.

Broad ranging terms of reference along those general lines, would, perhaps, be the most appropriate way of opening up for reasoned public and parliamentary debate questions which I think are becoming overdue in their need for consideration. This is a matter which I do not float any more precisely than that at this stage. I think it is a matter on which there should be discussion and consultation within all the parties, with the individuals who make up this Parliament, before hurtling down that track. But I float the possibility on this occasion of such a Senate committee of inquiry as being one of the more usefully constructed ways we might proceed in dealing with this kind of legislation in the future.

I acknowledge the points that were made by Senator Hill and which have been made by other contributors to this debate in the past about the essentially rubber stamp character of this legislative exercise in which we are engaged. I appreciate that it is not a terribly satisfactory state of affairs for any legislature to be reduced to that kind of role, acting at the request of an outside body, a ministerial council. It disrupts the traditional and familiar lines of governmental accountability. That is one of the basic reasons why I continue to hold the fairly strong view that a co-operative scheme is not the long term solution to our legislative problems in this area. With those comments I commend this Bill which, in its own terms is essentially uncontroversial, to the Senate. I thank honourable senators for their support and wish the Bill a speedy passage.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise with the Attorney- General (Senator Gareth Evans) some specific questions on the definition of time sharing but before I do so I will deal briefly-I will do so now rather than at the third reading stage-with the future consideration of the scheme and, in particular, the volume of legislation under it. I referred in my speech on the second reading of this Bill to the remarks I made in the debate last November on the Companies and Securities Legislation (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill 1983. It was a major piece of legislation amending the companies and securities legislation and it was foreshadowed as being an annual Bill. I think that what I said then is very relevant to what has been said by Senator Rae and the Attorney -General in his reply. In that debate on 16 November last year, as recorded on page 2681 of Hansard, I said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . I believe it will be necessary for this Senate either to set up a special committee to cope with it-
that is, with this sort of legislation-

or to set up a standing committee of the Senate to do so, which I think would be a preferable course of action because it is very important that we do have a group of senators who will take an on-going interest in the matter and develop some expertise in dealing with the matters contained in this type of legislation . As I said, I just do not think we are in any way equipped to handle it under the ordinary procedures we have embarked upon at the present moment.

The lengthy remarks I made at that stage and later were in relation to the volume and complexity of the legislation and the need to involve this Parliament in what would be at least an annual exercise. But it may be even more often than that, as has been happening lately. From what the Attorney has indicated, these new arrangements may need further legislative changes. The position is that as a result of the way the scheme has been set up and is operating this Parliament is asked to be a rubber stamp. As I mentioned last year Parliament is in the process bypassed by everybody. From my experience last year, nobody who is concerned with changes to the scheme thinks of coming to the Parliament at all. That is simply because the reality is that this Parliament is asked just to rubber-stamp decisions of the Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities.

I think we have problems at two levels. Firstly, how are we going to cope with the operation of the scheme, at the parliamentary level, so long as it lasts? My suggestion there is that a standing committee be set up specifically to keep the legislation under review and that an exposure draft of the legislation be followed as a practice, so that a committee of that kind could be working on the legislation before it actually came up for debate here. We would then have a much more satisfactory debate than is possible under the present system. I certainly agree that we need a committee, I think preferably of the Senate, to do this job. However the Attorney-General is talking, as I understand it, of a select committee to look at the whole scheme to see whether it should be maintained or scrapped. I will give some further consideration to that idea. It would seem to me that that proposal might be considered to be tendentious because the object of that committee would be to get rid of the scheme.

TALK.START.PARA: —You used 'tendentious' in its proper sense.

—Yes. He has now learned the meaning of it. I think that is somewhat down the track. What I do think is an immediate requirement is that a committee of the Senate be set up-I suppose it would have to be a standing committee, under the rules-to consider this type of legislation whenever it comes to the Parliament. I think if that very important step could be taken in the near future by the Senate it would help in having a more satisfactory consideration of measures of these kinds.

SPEECH.PARA: I did foreshadow in my speech in the second reading debate that I had a number of specific questions to raise with the Attorney-General about the definition of time sharing. These are matters that have been raised by a body known as the Australian Time Sharing Resort Council, which claims to represent every developer and consultant in Australia interested in time sharing facilities. Because of the rush of this legislation through the Parliament that body was not able to make any representations about the matter to me or anybody else. I received these comments from it only after lunch today. I raise them now and hope the Attorney-General does not seek to dispose of them here and now but to give some thought to them before this legislation proceeds further in another place. I have given a copy of them to the Attorney so that he may be in a position to comment on them. Although I do not wish to discourage him from commenting on them, I think some of them may require a little longer consideration than has no doubt been possible.

TALK.START.PARA: —And again they may not; wait and see.

—That is for the Attorney to judge, of course, but I hope he will give them more consideration. I do not want to hold up the Bill unnecessarily over the matter, but I seek an assurance that the matters will be fully considered before the Bill comes up for consideration in another place.

SPEECH.PARA: The definition of time sharing, which is to be inserted into the legislation, and I think it appears a couple of times in the Bill, is:
. . . a scheme, undertaking or enterprise-

(a) participants in which are, or may become, entitled to use, occupy or possess, for 2 or more periods during the period for which the scheme, undertaking or enterprise is to operate, property to which the scheme, undertaking or enterprise relates; and
(b) that is to operate for a period of not less than 3 years;'.

The concern is that this definition is capable of application to a large number of schemes or enterprises which do not come within any concept of time sharing and which would not be intended to be covered by such a definition. The first question is, for argument's sake, a lease with a three-year option. I must say that I do not find that a particularly likely example to be caught by the definition. Perhaps it could be considered. Secondly, there are contracts for the use of public entertainment or sporting facilities, such as the use of a football ground once a week or something of that sort. That may have some greater relevance. Thirdly, there are computer sharing contracts. Fourthly, there are contracts with an airline to provide hotel accommodation for package tours. I suppose that is what the Bill has in mind. Fifthly, there are credit card facilities; and sixthly, there are universities and educational institutions in relation to students who attend courses for more than three years. Although the Australian Time Sharing Resort Council has had discussions with the NCSC following its paper on the subject in July 1983, to which the Attorney referred in his second reading speech, the NCSC issued a policy statement indicating the circumstances in which it was prepared to relax some of the provisions of the legislation in respect of schemes. Although there has been consultation, this body has had no opportunity of consulting the Government in relation to this definition and it has raised the problems which I now put down for further consideration by the Attorney.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I acknowledge the opening points made by Senator Durack as to the volume and complexity of this companies legislation and the desirability of there being a greater parliamentary involvement in that legislative process. Of course the difficulty about upgrading parliamentary involvement in the way that has been indicated both by Senator Durack and Senator Rae, with a standing committee working over the details of legislation, is that there is a certain incongruity about that kind of process in the context of the present legislative arrangements where the Commonwealth is, as it were, not a free agent but merely the legislative agent of the Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities. It would work only for there to be really significant parliamentary committee type involvement in the process, where either the committee operated in an environment of very long time -lagged exposure drafts, which are not always possible, or alternatively if the committee were to be operating in an environment, as Senator Hill was last year, where he was putting down comments knowing that there was not much chance of their being accommodated in the context of the then current debate but in the hope that they would be accommodated next time around. There may be a role for the committee in that respect but it is difficult in the present co-operative scheme arrangements to have a better committee role than that. It is against that background, with that in mind and not because of any tendentious inclinations on my part--
—Used in its correct sense, of course.

—I hardly need to add that it is used in its correct sense. I am not in the habit of using the English language otherwise than in the correct sense. It is in that context that I did float the proposal quite explicitly today for a Senate committee to look at the larger question of the whole future of the co-operative scheme. It is by no means an open and shut question because even if one were determined to go down that particular policy path, very real questions have to be explored about the reach of the Commonwealth's constitutional power and in particular as to whether or not section 51 (XX), the corporations power, will do all the jobs that it is necessary to do in this area to enable an effective national package of companies and securities legislation to be put together. That is just one of the matters that will be very much in issue and which would need to be explored by such a committee. That is the reason for putting the proposal in those terms rather than simply acceding with enormous enthusiasm to the idea of a monitoring or review committee while the present co-operative scheme stays as it is. I do not rule out the idea of such a monitoring or review committee; I just think it would be of limited utility while the co-operative scheme continues to stagger on in the way that it does. Perhaps these are matters that can be further debated by us both privately and publicly in the period ahead.

SPEECH.PARA: The more particular matter that Senator Durack raised concerned the effectiveness of the definition of time sharing to confine its operation to what it is manifestly intended to cover, and that is the marketing of time-sharing arrangements in the context essentially of resort accommodation, which is the area in which time-sharing schemes have become most familiar. The criticism is that the definition of time sharing has been expressed so broadly that it might inadvertently catch a variety of investment schemes or activities other than time-sharing activities strictly so called. This is something which the Government will have another look at, as Senator Durack invites us to do, in the period between this debate and that in the House of Representatives to ensure that we really have done the best we can so far as this definition is concerned. We really do believe that it is not likely to catch unintended arrangements of the kind that are here suggested. I noted that even Senator Durack was cautious about embracing the particular proposal-

TALK.START.PARA: —I am cautious about all of them.

—I appreciate that sometimes the honourable senator is only the mouthpiece of lobby groups and that he cannot be expected to embrace the various positions they put to him with more than token enthusiasm.
—I am only a mouthpiece because of the rush in which this is going forward. I have not had time to think about it; nor have you.
—It has been only 10 days and I appreciate the difficulties to which that gives rise.
—It has been only about two hours.

—The honourable senator had the Bill, with respect, Tuesday last week and we are now into the second week of the parliamentary period. I deal quickly with a couple of points Senator Durack raised. Common three-year leases with a three-year option are manifestly not the kinds of things that will be covered by this definition. The definition relates to two or more periods during the time of the scheme; that is, shorter periods within the duration of a marketed scheme as a whole. It is certainly difficult to see how a three-year lease which continues for the whole period of three years could possibly be caught by the definition. The other more general point to make not only about that but also about all the other examples that are given-public entertainment, sporting facilities, computer sharing contracts, hotel or permanent accommodation agreements and so on-is that the difficulty about all of these things is that they ignore one of the central elements in the definition of prescribed interest in the parent Act, section 169 of the Australian Companies Code, which makes it clear that what we are talking about here are schemes which are offered to the public, and something which is in the nature of a scheme. We have to have that element of offering to the public before we even get to first base in the context of the application of this definition because this definition is only a supplementary definition to make it clear that the existing rules and definitions of prescribed interests extend to this kind of arrangement . One has to read the definition of time sharing in the context, as I say, of all the prescribed interest provisions.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not think it is necessary to say more than that about time sharing other than that the definition will be kept under review. It certainly can be amended if examples come to light of schemes which have been inadvertently caught or alternatively recourse can be had to the exemption provisions in scheme legislation relating to prescribed interests. That is in section 215C of the Companies Act and section 16 of the Companies (Applications of Laws) Acts in each State. I think I have addressed the particular matters as well as the general ones that Senator Durack has raised and I hope that we can now proceed to a vote on the Bill.
Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.
