DEBATE.TITLE: SATELLITE COMMUNICATIONS BILL 1984SATELLITE COMMUNICATIONS (CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1984

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 28 March, on motion by Senator Grimes:
That the Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is considering the Satellite Communications Bill 1984 and the Satellite Communications ( Consequential Amendments) Bill 1984. The purpose of the legislation is to entrench Aussat Pty Ltd in legislation and to define its role and structure. This legislation will serve a number of purposes. It confirms the commercial basis of the operation of Aussat. It declares that, together with Telecom Australia, Aussat will provide the national telecommunications network of Australia. It states the obligation of the directors of Aussat. It confirms the status of Aussat as a private company and authorises the sale of up to 25 per cent of the company to Telecom at a total cost of $21.2m. It prevents Aussat from providing public switched telephone or data services. It prevents third party use of leased satellite capacity. It permits Aussat users to operate their own earth facilities and as a result of this legislation it can be wound up only by a resolution of both Houses of the Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: It is therefore very significant legislation which will have far-reaching and significant effects in relation to the operation of Aussat and the operation of Australia's satellite. The Opposition welcomes these Bills which give effect to the national domestic satellite system which Aussat Pty Ltd will operate. It is interesting that the whole idea of a satellite system is one which the Australia Labor Party a few years ago bitterly attacked. I have a Press release issued by Senator Susan Ryan on 18 August 1979 in which she said, inter alia:

The establishment of a separate satellite authority is not the rational way to develop Australian telecommunication services. It would result in loss of revenue for Telecom and seriously erode the value of the public's $6,500 million investment in Telecom.

That was the view of Senator Ryan, speaking for the ALP in 1979. We are delighted that her Party has chosen to ignore the sentiments expressed in that Press release and to proceed with this legislation. The Bills will introduce to Australia a new era of communications providing for a comprehensive telecommunications capability which at present we do not enjoy. Much credit for this legislation must rest with the former Government and some of its Ministers. This process began in 1977. At that time the former Government established the national communications task force to investigate the feasibility of a domestic satellite system.

As I mentioned, in 1979 Senator Ryan thought the process was sufficiently advanced to complain about it and to criticise the concept on behalf of the Australian Labor Party. But the Liberal-National Party Government pressed ahead and in November 1981 Aussat Pty Ltd was incorporated by the Fraser Government as a wholly government-owned company. We would like to say how gratifying it is that the present Government is continuing the process, picking up the framework, and continuing the thrust of what we began. I congratulate the Government and assure it that it has our support in terms of the general direction it is taking . Insofar as the Government is picking up the procedures and the framework we developed, we are delighted to see what is emerging.

It is widely acknowledged that the satellite will be of enormous benefit to the entire Australian community. Its introduction comes at a time when a revolution is occurring in communications technology around the world. The benefits of this new technology and its application through Aussat will be enormous. We are aware that many isolated communities will be provided with a direct broadcasting service for television and radio, a service that has not been possible for some of them by any kind of terrestrial means. It has not been possible in some cases because of technical limitations; in other cases it has not been possible because of the costs involved, even if the technology was there. Air navigation and emergency services communications will be improved. Telephone services will be extended to remote areas of Australia beyond existing planned or terrestrial communications systems. I observe that I have very good friends living inland just behind Bodalla in New South Wales. In the last 10 years they have actually lost their telephone service. They used to have a direct home telephone service which they have now lost as a result of certain economies that took place. For people like them, living perhaps only 30 miles from one of the coastal towns, there will be the capacity now for telephone services which are necessary.

The satellite will provide for expanded and enhanced communications for the business and financial community. Of course, very importantly, it will provide for an expansion and enhancement of distance education for many Australians who are not able at present to get access to educational institutions. School of the Air and other distance education initiatives can be developed and expanded. In this way the benefits of education technology can be brought closer to students even if they live in the most remote parts of Australia. When I was Minister for Education I became aware of the great disadvantage suffered by many of the students in remote areas. I am delighted that the satellite will go some way towards equalising the opportunities for those people who are forced to rely on services such as the School of the Air for their education. I pay tribute in passing to the work done on behalf of these isolated children by the group of parents who act on their behalf, the Isolated Children's Parents Association. As a group representing special interests it has been one of the most positive, reasoned and constructive groups with which it has been my pleasure to deal over a number of years.

I have indicated the benefits which we think will flow from the satellite. I refer back to my experience as Minister for Aboriginal Affairs and say that I think there could also be some detriment. Having travelled in some of the most remote parts of Australia, for example to some of the areas in the Pitjantjatjara homelands where a number of Aboriginal people have been living a traditional lifestyle, I know that one of the things that has maintained that lifestyle has been the cultural unity within that community. I think we will have to accept that with the advent of the kind of popular entertainment that we regularly put on television in this country there may well be some destructive effects upon that kind of community as it tries to maintain its cultural identity. It is already difficult enough, as honourable senators will know, when Aboriginal people move into centres of population. I think the enhanced communications will have some detriment to these people as well as some benefit for them. As long as we are aware of that and are willing to address that problem and not run away from it we can still hope that the beneficial effects will outweigh the costs.

The Opposition therefore supports the legislation and we will not oppose the Bills at the second reading stage. We do have some reservations about aspects of the legislation which I will outline by way of amendments in Committee. I add that there is an amendment we wish to move in relation to one of the Bills at the second reading stage. Because of the procedures the Senate has adopted, about which the Opposition is quite happy, we have a second reading amendment which I will introduce at this stage before I go on to discuss some of our concerns. I move:

At end of motion, add ', but in relation to the Satellite Communications ( Consequential Amendments) Bill 1984 the Senate is of the opinion that companies formed, or participated in, by the Australian Telecommunications Commission and partnerships entered into by the Commission, should be subject to the same tax and dividend requirements, etc., as competing commercial companies'.

The amendment refers, as I have indicated, only to the Satellite Communications (Consequential Amendments) Bill, but because of the way we handle these Bills I move it as an amendment to the cognate second reading motion. The amendments which the Opposition will propose and the areas about which we have concern or to which we are opposed are: First, the obligations of the directors of Aussat Pty Ltd; secondly, the Telecom Australia shareholding; and thirdly, the restrictions on third party private data and voice traffic which will be permitted through Aussat.

The Opposition strongly supports the requirement for Aussat to operate as a completely commercial company as is detailed in the legislation. The Government has our support on that aspect. The Opposition supports Aussat being able to direct its own telecommunications facilities for satellite links. The Government has our support for the proposal that private companies using the satellite are to be allowed to erect and operate their own earth stations. But we are concerned that this legislation gives the impression that Telecom is being unnecessarily protected by some of the terms of the legislation and by some of the restrictions. This is in no small way due to the enormous pressure that certain unions have exerted on the Government. I have just one of the Press releases put out in relation to satellite legislation in the name of the ATEA, the Australian Telecommunications Employees Association. It was signed by Mr W. C. Mansfield, the Federal Secretary of the Association. It suggested to the Government a far more centralised and unitary system. I congratulate the Government for withstanding some of that pressure and for continuing to promote Aussat as an independent company. But there has been enormous pressure put on the Government to give certain protections to Telecom. Some aspects which in some way might threaten Telecom's stake in the communications sphere are matters to which the union has objected.

I will concentrate just a little more on several aspects of this good Bill to which the Opposition will object and about which we are not happy. The first concerns the obligations of the directors of Aussat. The Bill as drawn stipulates that as far as practicable the directors are required to ensure that space facilities should be made available for: First, air navigation and related safety services; secondly, Australian Broadcasting Commission remote area television and radio; and, thirdly, Telecom telephonic services for remote areas and emergency services. That is fine, but there was a fourth obligation contained previously which is now missing. What is not mentioned and what was in the original charter for Aussat and what has now been removed is the Government' s obligation, and Aussat's obligation, to provide for a free commercial television and radio service for people in remote areas of Australia. It is a matter of regret that that obligation on the part of the directors will be removed by clause 8 of the Bill.

It may be that the Government sees no mileage for itself in seeking to make obligatory the provision of commercial television and radio services to people in remote areas. However, the provision of commercial television and radio services to those people would increase their choice of programs. They can turn the dial of their radios and tune in to the broadcasts of the Australian Broadcasting Commission. In fact, usually I tune into nothing else on either the television or the radio. The argument at least can be advanced that those people who wish to listen to commercial radio or watch commercial television should have those services available to them. The providers of commercial radio and television services want those people in remote areas of Australia to have that option. The great majority of Australians take for granted the wide choice of radio and television services available. It is a matter of regret that, in spite of the difficulties that might ensure in determining how commercial radio and television organisations could participate in the scheme, the directors of Aussat are not required to fulfil that obligation. The Opposition will indicate its concern by moving an appropriate amendment at the Committee stage.

That leads me to deal with the question of ownership of Aussat. One of the most contentious aspects of the Bills has been that of ownership and the Government's decision that it would permit or require a certain number of shares to be held by Telecom Australia. The Government has been forced to change its policy in that regard. The Opposition believes that that was a direct result of pressure exerted by the Australian Telecommunications Employees Association on Caucus members during their discussions. The Opposition regrets that that policy change has occurred. It understands that a proposal was advanced that Aussat should be 100 per cent owned by Telecom. That is said to be the alternative if the Opposition does not agree to Telecom having 25 per cent ownership.

The Opposition's duty is to look at the principle and what is in the best interests of Aussat and the best long term interests of communications in Australia. The Opposition does not believe that it is necessary to ensure or that there is any real advantage in ensuring this cross linkage of ownership between Aussat and Telecom. Opposition members have some concern that Telecom, which already has enormous responsibilities, may not need or may not have the kinds of interests to be involved directly with a satellite or that, if it is interested and does become involved, it may have vested interests of its own that may not necessarily be completely congruent with those of Aussat Pty Ltd. The Opposition would be quite happy if Aussat were to remain a private company for the time being. At the Committee stage I shall move an amendment that will seek to confirm the present status of Aussat as a private company with all of its shares being owned by the Commonwealth. The Opposition simply sees no reason to sell off part of Aussat to Telecom Australia as is proposed.

The next matter of concern to the Opposition is to be found in clause 13 of the Satellite Communications Bill. Clause 13 prohibits Aussat from providing services of a kind known as public switch telephone or data services. As I mentioned earlier this prohibition will confirm for Telecom its existing monopoly in this area. The Opposition feels that it should examine carefully any proposal that seeks to preserve a Telecom monopoly in relation to activities that Aussat might take on or might be able to take on. The Opposition is concerned to ensure that the provisions of the Bills do not or should not prohibit Aussat from leasing transponder capacity for private companies or for the use of private organisations. However, it is the degree of additional use by a third person or what constitutes the limits of a company or an organisation for such purposes known collectively as third party traffic that is a matter of some debate in Australia and in other countries in relation to telecommunications generally. The Minister has given an assurance in another place that the Government's intention in restricting third party traffic by Aussat is, in his words, in line with existing regulation by Telecom of terrestrial services. The Opposition does not think that that means that Aussat will have equal rights to those of Telecom. The potential users of Aussat have complained vociferously that whilst Telecom is allowed to determine its own rules in relation to third party traffic, Aussat will be constrained by ministerial regulation in that area. At the Committee stage I shall move an amendment seeking to give Aussat exactly the same power that Telecom has in respect of third party traffic; that is, the power to determine its own regulations.

I have already mentioned that the Opposition has moved an amendment to the motion for the second reading of the second Bill in this package of Bills. That amendment expresses our general concern and the concern of industry that any joint venture, subsidiary company or technical consultancy should be genuinely commercial and should be subject to commercial requirements similar to those to which any other company in the commercial world is subjected. Having said all that, I point out that the Opposition believes that the legislation offers to Telecom Australia and to Aussat Pty Ltd a great opportunity in the area of communications development. It offers a great opportunity particularly to remote Australia. The Opposition believes that it offers a great opportunity in the area of new commercial ventures and new commercial opportunities.

The Opposition supports the Bills with the few reservations that I have mentioned. We welcome the Bills. We wish Aussat every success. We wish every success to the activities that are planned for Aussat. We hope that the people in remote Australia will get every advantage from this project. The Opposition urges the Government to give sympathetic consideration to the amendments that I have foreshadowed because they are offered in a spirit of co-operation and compromise on a package of Bills that the Opposition is supporting and in relation to which it congratulates the Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats support this project enthusiastically. We look forward to the satellite providing diversified broadcasting services to the remote areas of Australia. Senator Peter Baume touched on the history of this matter. The Fraser Government proposed that Aussat Pty Ltd be 51 per cent government owned and 49 per cent privately owned. As we understand it, the Hawke Government agreed with that proposal, at least in principle, in its economic statement of May 1983. The Australian Democrats supported the position the Government took. Ideally we still support the proposal that Aussat be 51 per cent government owned and 49 per cent privately owned. Having looked more closely at the proposal that it be 49 per cent privately owned, I am now starting to have second thoughts as to whether that is a practicable proposition. Obviously the Liberal Party would prefer Aussat to be 49 per cent privately owned because that is the proposition it put forward.

SPEECH.PARA: In the past the number of people who own and control television stations has diminished. With intertwining shareholdings and what have you in these companies it is very difficult to police their ownership in the way that all of us would like to. I have read papers that suggest that it would be possible for three or four powerful groups to gain a large enough share of a 49 per cent holding to make the management of Aussat biased. At least it would endanger the independence of the board of directors of Aussat. Notwithstanding that, as a point of principle, the Australian Democrats would favour 51 per cent government ownership and 49 per cent private ownership, with the reservation I have just mentioned.

In August 1983 Caucus overturned the proposal that Aussat be 51 per cent government owned and 49 per cent privately owned. It decided that 25 per cent of Aussat should be made available to Telecom. At the time the Australian Democrats announced their disappointment at that decision. We were disappointed for two reasons. Firstly, Telecom, having opposed the purchase of a satellite initially, was a late comer to the proposal and, secondly, Telecom had an unchallenged monopoly. We believed that diversity was needed through an independent Aussat. The Satellite Communications Bill which we are discussing enables Telecom to purchase 25 per cent of Aussat, among many other provisions. The basic position of the Democrats is to minimise, as far as possible, Telecom influence. We opposed 25 per cent because we would have preferred nought per cent involvement of Telecom per se. However, it has been made clear to us from several sources that there is a likelihood, if not a certainty, of Telecom gaining 100 per cent of Aussat if the 25 per cent share of this Bill is defeated.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is almost blackmail.

—That is one word for it. It is almost blackmail. I believe-and this will influence the way I vote-that if the Senate amends the Bill and it goes back to the House of Representatives it then has to go to Caucus again. I understand that if it does go back to Caucus it will be scrapped and, by another method, Telecom will totally control the satellite. Possibly Aussat will be disbanded and a space division will be established in Telecom to take over the project to ensure that the satellite goes ahead as close to schedule as possible . I think that would be the worst of all worlds. If Senator Baume wants to call it blackmail or almost blackmail I do not think I would disagree too much with him. I am not going to run the risk of sending this Bill back to Caucus and letting it roam at large. Members of the Press, who normally accurately report meetings of Caucus, have informed us that at the time the 25 per cent shareholding got up in Caucus some members of the Australian Labor Party were not present-they were marooned in mid air-but had they been there it would have been a 100 per cent Telecom owned proposition. That, with great respect to Telecom-and I have great respect for Telecom-would have been the worst of all worlds. Therefore, we believe we would be running a great risk, if this Bill were amended in the Senate, if it did eventually lend control to Telecom.

SPEECH.PARA: The Leader of the National Party of Australia, Mr Sinclair, has said-I apologise if I quote him wrongly-'That would not be too bad for us', namely, the National Party and the Liberal Party, the Opposition, 'because it would be easier to unscramble an egg after we return to power'. If Telecom owned the lot a Liberal-National Party government could then sell the lot to private enterprise. That is a fairly cynical view because what will happen to the people who will benefit from Telecom in the meantime-in the one year, four years or however many years it will be-before the Liberals and the Nationals return to power? Many people in outback Australia enjoy public broadcasting. A whole host of people who would benefit from these Bills would suffer during that interregnum. That is another reason we feel it would be irresponsible for the Senate to send the Bill back.

I can understand the point put by Senator Baume and the Government. I have sympathy with it, for the reasons I have given, but clearly the Senate is faced with a dilemma. We have come to the decision that we will, with reluctance, accept the Telecom 25 per cent share. We note with interest and are thankful that the shares cannot exceed 25 per cent and that the percentage cannot be changed unless it is done by an Act of this Parliament. At the same time, because we are deeply concerned that, notwithstanding the limitation of a 25 per cent shareholding by Telecom, by some device or devices Telecom can get virtual control of Aussat by getting a disproportionate number of directors on the board . That would mean that Telecom could virtually control Aussat while being limited to 25 per cent.

I thank the Government deeply for agreeing to a suggestion that we have put that it will accept an amendment at the Committee stage that the number of directors that Telecom can appoint, or who are Telecom related, will be no more than 25 per cent of the total number. I understand that the Government will accept that amendment. I believe it improves the legislation in that Aussat will be protected by the Bill itself. A shareholding of no more than 25 per cent can be controlled by Telecom. Telecom related directors cannot be more than 25 per cent of the total number; in other words, two out of the 11 directors. We believe that, given the current political environment, Telecom's influence has been substantially limited. Given that the Government, Aussat and the private sector are happy, an independent and viable satellite program is assured. I hope that the Opposition will support the Democrat amendment.

I foreshadow an area of concern to the Democrats which is contained in the Bill . Aussat has to be a commercial enterprise. We support that. Aussat has to be paid adequately for its services. That is fine in principle, but what about those who would benefit greatly from the satellite but who cannot afford to pay? I refer to Aboriginal radio stations, educational institutions, public broadcasting stations, and so on. There should be some provision for cross- subsidisation within Aussat's budget.

TALK.START.PARA: —They may be able to pick up the transmissions through remote satellite stations.
—I hope so. I would like the sort of response that Senator Townley gave to come from the Minister when he rises to close the debate. With those few reservations, the Democrats support the project.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Townley Sen M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the Satellite Communications Bill and the Satellite Communications (Consequential Amendments) Bill and the amendments that the Opposition will be moving. The Bills give effect to the recent Government decision on the ownership and management of the national communications satellite system. Together the Bills express the Government's intention that the telecommunications system provided by Telecom Australia and the satellite telecommunications system provided by Aussat Pty Ltd shall together form one national telecommunications network for this country. The Minister for Communications, Mr Duffy, said in his second reading speech:

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian satellite system will provide enhanced broadcasting and telecommunications facilities for the provision of services that would not be possible, or would be prohibitively expensive, using terrestrial based systems. The unique nature of satellite technology means that distance is no longer a major inhibiting factor in bringing news, information and entertainment to all Australians, wherever they may live.
For this country it will become a new era in communications. Canada has had a satellite service for some 10 years. I believe Australia is somewhat slow in getting to that stage.

For the information of the Senate I will run through the background of the events leading up to the introduction of these Bills. In 1977 the National Communications Satellite Task Force was established by the then Government to investigate the feasibility of a domestic satellite system. The Task Force produced a report in July 1978 with the recommendation that the planning for an Australian satellite system proceed immediately. In October 1979, the Fraser Government announced its decision in principle to establish an Australian communications satellite system. Detailed planning for the system was undertaken to ensure that the technical specifications and overall satellite design satisfied the special communication needs of this country, particularly with regard to the remote and isolated communities which are scattered throughout Australia. The Government identified the Overseas Telecommunications Commission as the interim owner and manager of the satellite pending the formation of Aussat. Aussat Pty Ltd was incorporated in November 1981 as a wholly government owned company. The memorandum of association provided for the sale of some shares to the private sector.

In October 1980 the Government announced, as Senator Chipp said, that it would float some 49 per cent of Aussat's equity on the share market. The Hawke Government, in its economic statement of May 1983, accepted that policy in principle but later, in July 1983, Caucus recommended that this decision be overturned and that the management of the satellite system be integrated with Telecom. Both Senator Chipp and Senator Peter Baume mentioned the amount of pressure that was put upon certain members of Caucus by some of the unions to see that that happened.

The Australian Telecommunications Employees Association was adamant that Aussat be merged with Telecom in order to prevent competition. The Government agreed to that and in a Press release dated 15 November 1983 the Minister for Communications announced the Government's decision to retain Aussat as a separate Commonwealth owned company which would operate as a commercial taxpaying enterprise. We have already said that we very much agree with Aussat being operated on a commercial basis. The Government also decided that Telecom would be invited to purchase up to 25 per cent of the Government's shareholding in Aussat. There is really not much difference between Telecom having 25 per cent and the Government having the lot except that, as Senator Chipp mentioned a moment ago, it would be very much more difficult in the future to make the whole satellite system a commercial venture rather than a government owned one, if such a decision were ever made by any government in the future.

As I have said, we in the Opposition support these Bills. We welcome them. They bring to fruition an idea that the Australian Labor Party once attacked. We have been told by Senator Baume that, as well as there being benefits to certain sectors of remote areas in Australia, there could well be detriments. I hope that the Government will take on board his ideas and make sure that any detriments are kept to an absolute minimum. Senator Baume also mentioned in his speech the omission of one of the obligations of the directors. He mentioned that the Bill states:
The Directors of Aussat shall ensure that, so far as practicable, Aussat is able to meet the requirements for space satellite facilities-
(a) of the Commonwealth for the purpose of the provision and maintenance of air navigation facilities and related safety services;
(b) of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation for the purpose of the provision by the Corporation of television and broadcasting services to remote communities and dwellings; and
(c) of the Commission for the purpose of the provision of telephonic services in remote areas and of emergency services.

The major omission, though, was the obligation on the directors, which was previously in the structure of Aussat, to give commercial television and radio some kind of transmission via the satellite. I ask the Government: Why should not people in remote areas be allowed another frequency apart from ABC radio and television stations? Why should there not be commercial radio and television, even in spite of the difficulties that will be found in trying to decide who would get that commercial outlet?

It certainly seems to me, coming from an area where we have fairly limited television-in Hobart we have only two television stations, an ABC one and a commercial one-that to have one channel limits the people in the outback in a way that they should not be limited in this modern age. From a technical point of view, there is absolutely no reason why they should be limited. It certainly seems that a dual service, with provision for even more expansion as the cost of earth receiving stations comes down, is a good idea. I believe the Minister in the other place said that it was the Government's intention at some stage to take into account this matter and to have commercial stations. But I would prefer to see that requirement in these Bills so that the Senate knows exactly what is going on.

I will not go into the ownership of Aussat. It has been dealt with by both Senator Chipp and Senator Baume. The Opposition, whilst not agreeing entirely with the way the Government is dividing up the ownership, is not particularly distressed by it although we would like to see somewhat different arrangements.

I will be pleased to see the launching of this satellite come to fruition in 1985. I hope that the piece of machinery that is launched does not meet the fate of a couple of other satellites that were launched recently by the United States of America. I think they were owned by India and Indonesia. I am sure that we will take care to see that our satellites do not get into that kind of situation .

This is an interesting advancement in communications in this country. As the Minister said in his second reading speech, it will complement Telecom's present service rather than compete with it. I believe that in some areas perhaps Telecom should have some competition. As an electronic engineer I will watch with much interest the future development of this satellite. In closing I say that we welcome the Bills. We note that the ALP once attacked the principle. We have some reservations that Senator Baume has mentioned. We have moved an amendment to the second reading motion and we will move some amendments at the Committee stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The introduction of Australia's domestic satellite system is, of course, a major landmark in the history of the nation's communications system. It is particularly important to me that the domestic satellite offer people in remote areas access to radio and television services. In many cases this has not been possible in the past. However, tonight I wish to raise some of the concerns that have been put to me by both the Australian Broadcasting Corporation and a regional television station, North Queensland Television, regarding the maintenance of local identity within regional areas. As honourable senators are probably aware, I am inclined to keep arguing that it is very important that regional areas maintain their local identity. While there are obvious benefits to all Australians in being able to tune into national news , sporting events, quality entertainment and educational programs beamed from capital cities, I argue and so do many people in regional areas that there are equal benefits to be gained by regional communities receiving news, sport, weather and general information programs about local areas and topical events.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that it is most important to remind ourselves of the disadvantages inherent if a realistic balance is not maintained between those two positions. I wish to cite an example. Last Friday in Brisbane the choice of television in that capital city was between Australian current affairs, which I hasten to assure honourable senators I chose, and three American crime programs which offered very little variety, very little choice to the viewer and very little in the area of quality entertainment. One may well ask then, what is the purpose of having access to three commercial channels if 'canned crime' is monopolising prime viewing time in capital cities.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not all that is shown. That is the thing. Countdown on the ABC is not a great program for all of us.

—I might say that many of the young people enjoy it. We do not want to see an extension of the situation that I have outlined developing in regional and remote areas of Australia where viewers, it could be argued, could be obliged to accept the often dubious choice of city-based programmers. I return to the representations that I have received from people concerned about regional input. I wish to raise a particular concern about ABC television in central and northern Queensland from Rockhampton and Townsville under the proposed Homestead and Community Broadcasting Satellite Service. Basically, it is proposed to install two earth stations, one in Rockhampton and one in Townsville. These dishes, or earth stations, will be equipped both to send and receive radio signals to and from the satellite. However, in relation to television, the situation is presently envisaged. The earth stations will be able to receive only and will not be equipped with 'up-link' capacity, that is, to send signals direct to the satellite from either Rockhampton or Townsville. In effect, it may mean a significant reduction in the program reach from either centre. This will certainly be the case if the terrestrial system currently in use is disbanded as a cost saving measure. It will mean that transmission cover will be restricted to areas immediately surrounding Townsville or Rockhampton associated with the power of their transmitters.

SPEECH.PARA: The decision to curtail the earth station capability is based on cost. To provide an earth station with two-way up and down linking will total around $5m whereas the more simplifed version will be approximately only $1m for both dishes. It appears as if the cheaper option could be considered. I would argue that regionalism in television is just as important as in radio. It would be a retrograde step to opt for the $1m version compared with the $5m version.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can it be upgraded later?
—I do not know whether it can be upgraded later. But I think that that is not good enough. I think we need to be assured that the preferable choice is instigated at the beginning of planning.

SPEECH.PARA: It is true that programming can be delivered from Brisbane to the outback via the satellite with the regionals providing material. However, it will be inevitably a macro coverage for all but the immediate environs of Rockhampton or Townsville. The consequence is a decrease in important regional coverage and identity. I trust, therefore, that the ABC will seriously consider the absolute priority of recognising the $5m version if north and central Queensland are not to be isolated in terms of their ability to transmit and contribute to programming in a direct and efficient manner. I know that people in this chamber will, as I have said before, tire of my reminding them that north and central Queensland are very distinctive regions with a total population considerably in excess of that of Tasmania. I think it would be unacceptable if such a decentralised region should inevitably be relegated to direct control from Brisbane. I am afraid that this sort of thing happens in a number of areas.

I also wish to raise the concerns of regional commercial television and in this regard I am certainly speaking in terms of future decisions of the Government. North Queensland Television in its submission to me documents the arguments for and against the three currently debated options for providing commercial television to remote areas outside the service areas of existing stations. It argues that option 1, the Homestead and Community Broadcasting Satellite Service II concept, is apparently problematic as the advertising revenue generated by the service would be insufficient to cover the cost of the four high powered transponders. In regard to option 2 it argues that subscription television is unacceptable as it would be totally discriminatory for people living in remote areas. Option 3, which provides for a networking arrangement to allow major networks to transmit directly to remote areas, is concerning for this station and I believe other regional stations. North Queensland Television claims that because the networks would be transmitting on national beams there would be no regard to time zones and censorship requirements. For example, adult only movies which were being shown in the east at 8.30 p.m. would be seen in Western Australia at 6.30 p.m. It is reported that the networks claim this problem is merely a distraction and is of such insignificance that it should not be allowed to detract from the benefits of remote areas audiences having access to three national commercial networks.

In the light of my experience which I outlined earlier I would perhaps question the benefits of access to three national commercial networks. Nevertheless, I think we do need to take the point that North Queensland Television has raised, that if the Government were to accept that view it could in fact make a mockery of everything that has gone before in regard to program standards and censorship regulations. It could, in fact, mean that the people in the outback would receive television signals originating out of Sydney or Melbourne with no local content and no orientation in programming towards the needs of remote area audiences. With three network signals in the outback there would be tremendous pressure on regional stations with only one or two transmissions to increase their program content in quantity but not necessarily quality. The influence on programming by the major networks would then be strengthened to the extent that in some of the smaller markets, regional stations could become virtually no more than relay stations for the major networks.

I would like to raise this evening a possible solution that has apparently been discussed. North Queensland Television has proposed that a possible solution would be for State governments to become involved in the provision of a second Homestead and Community Broadcasting Satellite Service. While on this occasion I will not go into the details of this proposal, I know that this information has been forwarded to the Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy) and I think it is well worth consideration. I believe that at the moment the Federal Government is conducting a review of the policy on localism in Australian commercial broadcasting to examine the extent to which localism should be maintained. Localism is at the heart of the existence of regional stations and should therefore be maintained and, in fact, further developed. Modern communications via the satellite offer an outstanding opportunity for the extension of media services throughout Australia, but we must ensure that diverse regions throughout this extensive country of ours are not in fact swallowed up by an absolute concentration of programming in capital cities and larger provincial areas. I hope that ongoing discussion of the issues I have raised will in the long term lead to acceptable compromises which will in fact give recognition to the role of regional stations in reflecting and catering for the communities they represent.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Satellite Communications Bill lays the foundation for an exciting development in Australia's life. The satellite will bring communications systems to those people who live in the remote areas of our vast country. Although I join Senator Baume in congratulating the present Government and its predecessor on bringing this legislation to finality, there are a number of aspects in this Bill that will involve problems for us all, and particularly for Australians in remote areas. I concur with Senator Baume's remarks about the structure of Aussat, its relation to Telecom and the Opposition's stance on these matters. I also concur with Senator Reynolds, who rightly reflected the interests of the people of north Queensland. I shall endeavour to do the same in regard to the interests of the people in South Australia in the vast northern areas of my State.

SPEECH.PARA: About a year ago, after the election of the present Government, the future of Aussat was in some doubt. There were pressures on the Government to delay or seriously change the pattern of developments set in train by the former Government. I am happy to see that, despite those pressures, the present Government has endorsed the initiatives set in place and that Aussat will be on time. The satellite should be operating towards the end of 1985. I warmly congratulate the Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy) and the other Ministers for the continuing progress in the achievement of the satellite. Some 300,000 people in remote parts of Australia do not have the usual access to telephones, radio and television. They represent some four or five electorates in terms of the House of Representatives and should have some political clout within Parliament. They and others in remote areas of the country are somewhat dispersed over 10 electorates. Fortunately, the Opposition parties represent most of them and one hopes that we shall one day represent them all. We must take up the interests of Australians in remote areas and ensure that the facilities afforded by the satellite will be used to the best effect in improving the quality of their lives.

One hears a great deal, not least from those of us in the Senate who are concerned about education policies, about equality of opportunity. We talk about equality of opportunity between government and non-government schools. In regard to the sex discrimination legislation, we talk of equality of opportunity betwen men and women to ensure that there is similar access to jobs or accommodation. We talk about equality of opportunity in the work force when we consider the tragic situation faced by the unemployed. We talk of young Australians having equality of opportunity in finding their share of the jobs that are available. But what about equality of opportunity for Australians in remote areas? Only infrequently does one hear about their needs, and even less frequently does one hear those needs put in terms of equality of opportunity. Honourable senators in all parties often consider the goals of equality of opportunity for black Australians, white Australians, women, men, the young and the old. We should think in similar terms of the needs of those who live in remote Australia.

Those needs lead me to outline two problems related to the satellite development. The first is the educational needs of isolated children. In the second reading speech on the Satellite Communications Bill the Minister spoke of the great boon provided by the satellite to communications. He said that it would bring 'news, information and entertainment to all Australians, wherever they may live'. Unfortunately, in those happy phrases the Minister did not mention education. He went on to say:

Clearly, the satellite will be a boon to those living in the more remote and outback regions of Australia. It will bring to those Australians the benefit of ABC radio and television services, through the Homestead and Community Broadcasting Satellite Service.

However, the Minister did not mention education services or the educational gains from such a satellite. In the discussion in the last few years the public has become excited at the hope of a boon not only in the area of news, information and entertainment communication but also in education. As the dimensions of the practical outworking of the satellite become clearer and clearer as this country approaches 1985, there is fear and concern throughout remote areas of Australia that little indeed will be made available in terms of educational services.

Let us consider some of the reasons for this state of affairs. I understand that the Australian Broadcasting Corporation television service will be provided through four footprints-four regional ABC television programs. There will be one station for Western Australia, a second involving the Northern Territory and South Australia, a third for Queensland and northern New South Wales and a fourth for New South Wales, Victoria and Tasmania. Those four footprints receiving ABC television will have some ability to program educational material, whether for children or for adults, at appropriate times as a part of the overall programs throughout the week. There will be some regional diversity since at least there are four footprints, but I understand that the commercial television provided by the satellite will in every instance be national-in other words, one footprint for the whole of Australia. There will not be scope for regional diversity; it will be one national program. If a commercial television station were to program some educational material, all well and good, but it will not have the flexibility which Australians have become used to in the School of the Air programs. They are highly localised and geared to particular educational needs and there is a great deal of feedback from local regions.

As I have outlined, the television services from the satellite will have this four-pronged ABC approach and one, two or three national commercial broadcasting approaches. But even if that range of television gives a one-way communication of some useful educational program-especially for children but also for adults, and not least paying regard to the particular needs of Aboriginal communities- there will not be very ready access to a two-way communication process. It will cost any isolated homestead or dwelling an estimated $1,500 to install the meter diameter dish that will be able to receive these programs. That is fine. Most families can save $1,500 over a few years even if they have limited means. In some areas where there is a concentration of 10 or 100 families access to receiving that one-way communication will be even cheaper. Some material will come down from the satellite but there will not be the ability to transmit back up. The cost of the facility for two-way traffic will be 10 times the outlay of $1,500. It is estimated that it will cost $15,000 for any isolated family to be able to broadcast back up. I understand that the transponders and other electronic equipment in the satellite will not have the capacity to receive a response from a whole range of individual families involved in, say, a two-way idealised television communication in an educational mode.

I think the people in remote areas of Australia need to understand that it is no accident that the Minister has not referred to education as one of the great boons, as he put it, to come from the satellite. This is a real disappointment because in the last several years the expectation has been excited that there might be. It has also, to some extent, been excited by the presence of that excellent Australian, Mr Rory Treweeke, as one of the directors of Aussat. Mr Treweeke from northern New South Wales is the President of the Isolated Children 's Parents Association, that altogether responsible and exciting association Australia. It has been formed now for 13 years. It was initiated by the remote families of Australia in themselves to do something about the needs, especially education needs, of children on remote homesteads involved in correspondence schools and schools of the air and children taught next door to the kitchens of their mothers and fathers.

These marvellous people, working in difficult and remote areas, are amongst those Australians to be included as the salt of the earth. I noted the references of my colleague Senator Peter Baume to the ICPA earlier. I have been proud to be associated with the ICPA throughout the whole of my time in this place. A week ago my wife and I went to Port Augusta to the annual meeting of the ICPA. It was attended by representatives of families in the whole electorate of Grey, in the area from the Peterborough-Broken Hill road, east of Burra, around to Ceduna and to the places between, the Gawler Ranges and Coober Pedy. Unfortunately, some of the most remote communities such as the Pitjantjatjara communities around Marla were sufficiently remote that it was difficult for them to be represented at that annual conference.

At that conference I was again reminded that these families are the salt of the earth. They are marvellous people and they are responsible in what they are seeking. One of their highest priorities is the educational needs of their children. It is dawning upon family by family as these meetings see the fuller picture of what Aussat can provide that the educational opportunities will be very limited. There will be some indirect gains, such as the fact that there will be access to entertainment and television and radio voices in addition to the immediate surroundings of an isolated homestead. But if we are to speak about educational programming as part of a curriculum for year 3 or year 7 children, for an adult Aboriginal education program or for any other directly programmed educational objective, unless we see some breakthrough or hear some news beyond that which has been available to date the high expectations that have been excited in recent years will not be lived up to. I therefore make no apology in drawing attention to the fact that the Government, through the Minister's introduction of these Bills, has not referred to educational opportunities from the satellite. I make the point and underline it that we ought not to delude ourselves that some of the present programs of educational benefit to isolated families ought to be denied just because a satellite is coming.

Let me refer to the correspondence schools, the schools of the air and the educational video loan scheme. These are now well established facilities assisting families in remote areas but there is some assumption that because the satellite is coming in we may not need these programs and that the satellite will provide for all the remote communication needs. That is not true. Happily, Senator Button is in the Senate. I make a personal appeal to him that in the coming Budget there be confirmation of the moneys available for the home loan video scheme which assists children in remote families.

TALK.START.PARA: —Also within the satellite you would like to see some of that dedicated to education, still, would you not?

—I would still like to see that. Senator Peter Baume knows as does Senator Reynolds that the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts has considered my suggestion that we have a Senate inquiry into the educational opportunities made available by the satellite to see what can be achieved and how we can go about making sure that opportunities for educational programming through the satellite are achieved. Certainly we have not seen it yet from Aussat. We have not seen it in terms of the public inputs to the various inquiries that have been conducted by the Department or by Aussat itself . All the hopes that Senator Reynolds has expressed in broader terms about localised communication and the sorts of things I have been speaking about still want to be achieved by very many people in remote areas. Yet we have not got the mechanism or information to give assurance that they can be achieved.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said, Senator Button is in the chamber. I appeal to him as he is a senior Minister in the Budget process to ensure that there is confirmation of the moneys available for the home loan video scheme. At the moment an isolated child receives two video cassettes each fortnight from a production and distribution centre within the Education Department in each State. A team of people put together appropriate material, some of which includes the child's teacher communicating not only with the voice but, as it were, in person with a picture on the video cassette. They are specially prepared programs that are of interest and are more durable as part of a curriculum appropriate to each level of education. There is no assurance that money will be available for this scheme in any State of Australia after 30 June this year. The program is living on a year- by-year gasp. We need, particularly in the coming financial year, to see the continuation of this program and some statement of policy with regard to the relationship with Aussat and the satellite.
