TALK.START.PARA: —Before the suspension of the sitting for dinner, in the debate on the Satellite Communications Bill and the Satellite Communications ( Consequential Amendments) Bill I was referring to the educational needs of isolated children in remote areas of Australia and the lack of any direct reference in the Government's support of these Bills to any educational programming or indeed any educational advantage that will be specifically provided through the satellite.

SPEECH.PARA: In the minutes that remain I want to go on to a second large problem area which a number of people in the community have referred to already but which I do not think has been directly referred to in the debate in the House of Representatives or here in regard to these Bills, and that is, the detrimental impact that Aussat communications are likely to have on remote Aboriginal communities. Inevitably, from the end of 1985 the blanketing of Australian Broadcasting Corporation television and subsequently commercial television and radio programs will have a direct, visual and audible impact upon all of the Aboriginal communities in remote areas. In the last 200 years the more than 200 languages indigenous to Australia have been reduced to about 150. Of those 150 there are only 50 Aboriginal languages which can be called viable; that is, they have a community of at least 100 speakers. About only 10 have a community of speakers of more than 1,000 and some of those range up to 10,000. But of the 30, 000 Aboriginal people in remote communities speaking these 50 to 150 languages we now see the inescapable intrusion of mostly what we can predict will be English language problems compatible with all other Australian listeners, and that continuous blast of the language acceptable to the majority of us in Australia will have a detrimental effect upon the retention and maintenance of those remaining indigenous languages. Whilst this factor has been discussed in some parts of Australia it has not been discussed in the Parliament. I believe that even in Aussat there ought to be a realisation of the impact that television especially will have on these remote communities.

I do not wish to be entirely pessimistic because we ought to be looking to the advantages that any good new development in Australia will bring. I will certainly not deny that the Aboriginal communities of Australia will find advantages in information and in widened horizons and a greater understanding of the unity of Australia through the television programming. But let us see that Aboriginal education programs and processes are hit not only by the detrimental effects of television. In these last 200 years we have had the impact upon those communities of the diseases introduced by settlers in Australia that have decimated the population, and then the terror of alcohol and the detrimental effects it has had upon the Aboriginal people. I fear that the third big wave that will undermine the culture and integrity of the Aboriginal people will be this pervasive television.
One submission to an inquiry about satellite television which was put in by the Central Australian Aboriginal Media Association-CAAMA-which is based in Alice Springs, put it in these terms:
. . . the introduction of television to remote communities will have profound effects on the social, linguistic and cultural structures of traditional Aboriginal life.
We also believe that the satellite can either be a force for destruction or a powerful tool in the development of Aboriginal people.
Consequently, CAAMA feels that remote Aboriginal communities should have complete control over the introduction of any broadcasting services into their communities.

Now that plea at the end is just unrealistic. Given that as I pointed out before the dinner break there will be only four ABC footprints in terms of the target areas for the ABC broadcasts, it is totally beyond reality for one regional media association in Alice Springs to have some control. Maybe there will be a public broadcasting approach to the ABC programming that will allow public participation, including CAAMA, and including the Aboriginal communities direct. I put that to the Government and to Aussat.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has there been any consultation with the communities?

—There has been consultation with the communities but it has not reached any real threshold of awareness in the remote areas. I think there have been only small groups that have raised these social and educational questions. So I think that the hope expressed by CAAMA is unrealistic. But let us respond to the fears expressed and to the expression that there be more local involvement so that there can be programming that is responsive to the leadership of local communities themselves and a context of educational and social understanding of how to receive the new medium of English language television amongst these remote communities. I would also like to encourage the greater giving of resources to bilingual education schools in Aboriginal communities and, indeed, to adult educational programs that are bilingual because we will lose a great deal in Australia and in particular the Aboriginal communities will feel a great loss, if a pervasive English television saturation from 1985 denies the maintenance of local languages.

SPEECH.PARA: The two matters that I have especially tried to raise in my contribution to this debate are the two matters that have been totally omitted in the Government 's own statements in support of this legislation. Both of the matters are of an educational and social nature and deal with isolated children's educational needs and the context of Aboriginal communities and how they may be able, with encouragement, to gain positively rather than be devastated by this new medium that will be upon them. I genuinely urge the Government to make sure that resources are available for compensating measures, complementary to the advances that we will see through this new communications system.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Satellite Communications Bill 1984 and the Satellite Communications (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1984 are, as far as I am concerned, as a person who comes from the remote areas of Australia and who represents the Northern Territory, the most important pieces of legislation that I have seen before the Senate for quite a long time. They are important because the advent of Australia's own satellite, Aussat, which will be up and flying in 1985, will have a tremendous effect on the people of the outback.

SPEECH.PARA: A great deal of sophisticated communications equipment has been brought into use in the last decade. It has been very widely used in the highly populated areas of Australia, the eastern seaboard and our cities, but quite often the people who live in those places forget, or perhaps do not even know, the circumstances of many people who live in remote areas. I have lived in these remote areas since I was a child and so have been able to observe the situation. I can well remember that in the late 1920s my uncle was a radio ham. It was he who, in the bar room of the Stuart Arms Hotel, kept tapping out his morse, keeping contact not only with the hams around Australia but also, even in those days, with other countries. Alice Springs had a population then of about 140 or 160 people, with a few miners and pastoralists living in the area. The area was so remote that he was really the centre of communications. It was an incredible time. Very gradually communications in the outback struggled upwards. We had Flynn of the Inland and the pedal wireless set, on which the operators tapped away their message or endeavoured to get their voice over. They pedalled away to generate power, as though they were on a bicycle. Communications gradually progressed until eventually we had improved wireless and the radio telephone. The radio telephone was an enormous leap ahead, but it has not advanced very much over the years. I can say without any doubt whatsoever that communication in the outback is still very poor despite the sophistication and advantages of improved communication as other people know it.

This Aussat satellite that will cover the whole of Australia will bring to the people of the remote areas something that those in the cities take for granted. It will make a tremendous impact on the people. I wonder at times whether they consider what that impact will be because into their isolated homes will come communication systems and television not only from Australian cities but also from around the world. There are still very many isolated homes in the outback.

Senator Baden Teague made some reference to the Aboriginals. They are gradually finding their way through this new sophisticated world with which they are coming into contact more and more. One must consider what will happen to them. Press statements have been made recently regarding the Aboriginal people. I note particularly reports of two submissions to the inquiry into satellite program services, one by the Northern Territory Government and one by the Central Australian Aboriginal Media Association. The Association's submission says:
We also believe that the satellite can either be a force for destruction or a powerful tool in the development of Aboriginal people.
Consequently, CAAMA feels that remote Aboriginal communities should have complete control over the introduction of any broadcasting services into their communities.

The Association stresses that it would hope to provide some input itself and that there should be balanced programs which are educational, informative and culturally sensitive. The Northern Territory Government's submission says:

While it is true to say that many Aboriginal communities are already exposed to films and video programs of dubious quality, the impact of these and the detrimental effect already indicated will in no way compare with the damage that is likely to occur through saturation of second-rate material on a regular and intensive basis through AUSSAT.

Social impact studies in the Third World and of American Indians show the socially destructive effect of unsuitable programs, cultural destructiveness and the contribution to lawlessness and deliquency.
It would be naive to expect television not to have some detrimental impact on Aboriginal people and not to bring about some changes.

This notwithstanding, it is important that government support concerned Aboriginal organisations in their efforts to ameliorate the potential television has for damage to the social and cultural fabric of Aboriginal society.

So it goes on. One must consider, too, the children of the bush, whether living on mining fields or in pastoral homesteads. All these people will be affected by the satellite. I wonder what will happen. Senator Baden Teague raised the same query. It has not yet been said plainly what educational facilities will be available and what the input from local communities into the Aussat system will be. Will the School of the Air still be the dominant means of education? Thank goodness we have had the School of the Air because it has been tremendous for the children of the bush. Will Aussat improve the situation? Will programs contain such a national input that there will be no room for the children of the bush, including the Aboriginal children of the bush, to participate? Will it be just another type of television? While it will bring enjoyment to the people in the remote areas during their leisure time, what more will it contribute? I wonder. Nevertheless, I feel the satellite will be a tremendous thing.

I wonder, too, about the fact that people in the cities can switch on their sets and go from program to program and choose whatever they like. They can see national sport here and national sport there. Perhaps they watch it on Australian Broadcasting Corporation programs; perhaps not. Will Australians in remote areas be able to see those national sports which are of such appeal to the people in these remote areas? Is it a fact that the planning of Aussat has changed to such a degree that now we will see an ABC channel but not commercial stations? Why is it that people in the bush have to take what is given to them rather than what was promised to them?

TALK.START.PARA: —Who by?

—It was promised in the original planning of the satellite system. It was my understanding and that of the people at various conferences and such that the people of the bush would have a choice of program. Is it so much to ask for a second channel so that they can have a choice? Are they second -rate citizens? Do they have to be thankful for small mercies? I do not think the satellite is a small mercy. It is a tremendous thing. I am merely saying that surely the people of the bush should have the ability to turn that knob to a second channel. It is very doubtful that those people will have a second channel.

SPEECH.PARA: It has also been said, very unfairly, that the coalition partners, the former Liberal-National Party Government, actually impeded the process of bringing the satellite to Australia and to the people in remote areas. I note that the honourable member for the Northern Territory made that charge. On what grounds did he do so? As I see it, the project to bring to the people this enormous facility has been a joint effort between the previous Government and this Government. I do not think that in these circumstances political capital should be made of a situation that does not exist. There was also the criticism that somehow or other the coalition would have increased Telecom charges. I have yet to see substantiation of that claim. The question becomes one of how this Government envisages the arrangements for the administration of Aussat as against the arrangements envisaged by the previous Government.

I still do not see why private enterprise with a minority shareholding could not have had a say in the satellite. I think that all Australians would agree that control of Aussat should be firmly in the hands of the Australia Government . I agree with that, but I believe, as was initially planned, that 49 per cent of Aussat could be held by private enterprise. If a 49 per cent shareholding were held by private enterprise a tremendous partnership would have developed to the advantage of all Australians. I really do not see the necessity for the decision to have the satellite wholly owned by the Government with perhaps 25 per cent owned by Telecom.

I give tremendous support to Telecom. Its systems throughout Australia are doing a tremendous thing for Australia. We can be proud of Telecom and its technical advances. Nevertheless I ask why the Government, because of a particular union pressure, has found it necessary to give 25 per cent ownership to Telecom.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't be silly. You don't know what you are talking about.

—I appear to be getting some reaction from the Minister. As I have said, I believe Telecom is a tremendous organisation, but I do not see the necessity for its having a share in Aussat. It will be one of Aussat's main clients. I see absolutely no reason for it to hold that shareholding. I return very quickly to the point that a partnership could have been developed between private enterprise and the majority holding of Aussat by the Australian Government. I have been most interested in what has happened to communications in the outback. There is no doubt that in the next two, three or four years we will see enormous steps forward. In the last two days I have received an answer to questions I put to the Government through the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, (Senator Button) regarding Aussat and communications. I thank the Minister for that answer and take the opportunity very briefly to repeat parts of it. I think that it is a very good answer and indicates future directions. The answer states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Broadcasting Corporation will be provided with the resources necessary to establish and provide the Homestead and Community Broadcasting Satellite Service . . . which will enable people in remote areas to receive one ABC television service and at least two radio services.

I think it would be very good if there were a briefing paper of the services that will be brought forward by Aussat and by the ABC in the future. We know that in the next two years there will be high fidelity umbrella types of ABC transmitters in the Northern Territory. These transmitters will be at Katherine, Tennant Creek and Alice Springs. That high fidelity radio through an umbrella network of transmitters will be spread throughout the outback, so that people will receive ABC broadcasts whether they are on cattle stations, a mining field, an Aboriginal settlement, on horseback, in a droving camp or in a vehicle. I repeat that I believe these questions as to how the satellite and the ABC terrestrial system will operate should be answered in a briefing paper. The Minister's answer continues:

Funds and resources have been allocated to the Department of Communications to conduct tests of reception of television services by means of small low cost earth stations. When these tests are concluded, the Government will have the information on which technical standards for such earth stations will be determined.
This is of a lot of interest to people in the outback. The answer continues:

There has been a long standing program for the extension of television and radio services to remote communities and this is continuing. The program includes consideration, in particular instances, of extension by means of satellite rather than terrestrial distribution systems where this is shown to be the most cost effective means to adopt.

As an addition to the on-going program, the Government allocated funds from the 1983/84 budget to undertake further extensions to ABC (National) Services through the Remote and Underserved Communities Scheme which will extend radio to 12 nominated areas and television to a further 42 communities.
Once again, in the interests of the people of the outback, could there not be some more briefing material provided? The answer continues:

In addition, Telecom has announced a program to bring telephone services to remote areas by 1990 through the terrestrial network using Digital Radio Concentrator Systems (DRS) which are designed to extend the basic telephone service to more remote areas in the cheapest possible manner.

The cost of providing telephone services to the outback through the satellite system would be considerable. It is my understanding that in the initial planning stages the satellite was to provide telephone services to the outback. What has become of that proposal? The people concerned have not been told in a clear statement whether they can expect telephone services to be provided, as was indicated would be the case in the early planning stages of Aussat. Are they to receive telephone service through the satellite system, or has that proposal been changed? If it has been changed, was that done because of costs? Will the terrestrial network, using digital radio concentrator systems, be more effective and cheaper? Perhaps there is to be a combination of both systems. As I have indicated before, this matter is of tremendous importance to the people of the outback. They have been told so many different stories that they have become very confused. The answer I received continues:

Telecom has also announced the Iterra satellite service, designed to provide a range of switched and leased voice and data services for enterprises such as mining, exploration and tourist developments where service is required ahead of normal program-timing.
The technical and financial aspects of the provision of a telephone service to those few communities that will be reached by DRCS by 1990 are still under consideration.

The people of the outback are Australians and the satellite system is now being developed supposedly for Australians in remote areas. I think the Government could tell these people much more about the project. They are not second-rate citizens. I wonder what benefit these people will eventually receive from the project. The Coalition parties in the House of representatives have made clear their feelings about the various matters concerned with the ownership of Aussat and whether it should provide commerical radio and television services and what have you. However, they did not have the numbers in the House of Representatives and their proposals were defeated when put to a vote. The project has not been delayed. Although the coalition parties' original concept of Aussat has changed to some degree, the coalition has not delayed in any way the passage of the legislation establishing Aussat. This also applies to the coalition parties in the Senate.

It is not my wish to take the place of the Opposition senator who is responsible for communictions matters; I merely indicate that the Opposition has very strong feelings about the original concept of the satellite and the services it would provide. Some of those services are no longer to be provided. Because we do not have the numbers we will not be able to have the system that we desire. However, because the satellite means so much to the people of Australia the coalition parties would not consider disrupting the program that will result in Australia having its own satellite. I congratulate the Government on continuing with the project I represent approximately 150,000 to 160,000 people who are scattered over some 540,000 square miles. That is one person for every three square miles. The project is tremendously important to them.

The Isolated Children's Parents Association, which is an extremely active organisation, is concerned about many aspects of the proposal. Its members wonder how the satellite will have application to the education of their children. Will it mean a vast improvement in the education available to their children, or will the promises they have heard and read about come to nothing? An important consideration is whether people living in places other than the capital cities will have an input in the determination of the services that the satellite will provide. I do not have anything against the capital cities; I merely wonder whether the people of the outback will have an opportunity to have an input in the determination of whether their region will be provided with education facilities, news services and all those sorts of things that add to communication and the quality of life today. Senator Teague said that a receiving station will be established in Darwin from which broadcasts will be able to be received in the footprint covering the Northern Territory and the northern part of South Australia. If that is the case then there is some merit in the plans.

I return now to deal with the Aboriginal people. As I said before, the project will make an immense impression on the Aboriginal people. It will be foisted on them whether they like it or not. As I have said, CAAMA is concerned about this matter. The Northern Territory Government is concerned also. I ask very firmly- not suggest-that before the satellite is launched in 1985 all these matters to which I have referred be resolved.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Satellite Communications Bill and the Satellite Communications (Consequential Amendments) Bill. It is of very great concern to me and to many of the people I represent in Western Australia's remote regions that the policies of this Government in relation to the use of the satellite will prevent many of the potential benefits of the satellite from reaching the people for whom they were originally intended. The Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy) has frequently expressed his concern to provide services, including commercial services, to people who at present receive only a limited service or no service at all. Mr Duffy described the Federal Cabinet's decision of 13 July last year to proceed with the development of the national communications satellite as 'splendid news for the whole of Australia, and in particular for remote areas of the continent which have been isolated from adequate radio, television and telephone services for so long'. On 15 November 1983 Mr Duffy delivered to the House of Representatives a statement on the development of satellite related broadcasting services. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: Our major concern is to provide commercial services to Australians who are presently deprived of them.
In the same statement he went on to say:

The Government is most concerned about those areas where viewers do not have a choice of services. There is considerable imbalance at present between people living in large metropolitan areas, who can choose between two or three commercial television services, and those in regional areas who have only one service.
Doubtless many Australians will recall the rural policy speech made by the present Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, which he delivered in Griffith in February last year. Regarding the satellite he said:

We will give priority to ensuring that the domestic satellite . . . is used for the purpose for which it was originally intended-to provide better broadcasting and telecommunications services for outback communities.
Yet all these expressions of concern have been completely negated by this Government's decisions on the use of the satellite, in particular its pronouncement that:

Only the Australian Broadcasting Corporation will provide direct broadcasting services from the first two satellites. Commercial broadcasting uses of all transponders will be confined to national beams and will be encoded.

Quite simply, that means that remote and isolated communities will not now be able to receive commercial television. Each satellite has four of the powerful 30-watt transponders. The 30-watt transponders on the first satellite will be set in spot beams covering the north-east, the south-east and the western and central regions of Australia. The signal strength from these spot beams will be sufficient for reception by a small earth station costing around $1,000. These transponders have been set aside for the Australian Broadcasting Corporation to provide the Homestead and Community Broadcasting Satellite Service. This means that for the first time 315,000 people who have previously been without television will now be able to receive the ABC-whatever blessing that might be. However, it should be remembered that to do so they will have to pay $1,000 or more for a service that the great majority of Australians have already and, of course, take for granted.

Originally the four 30-watt transponders on the second satellite were envisaged as providing a backup to the Homestead and Community Broadcasting Satellite Service. It was soon realised that this would not represent the best interests of the satellite's capacity and the four transponders would be best used in providing a commercial homestead and community broadcasting service. The previous Liberal Government had clearly expressed its intention that this would be how the four 30-watt transponders on the second satellite would be used. In outlining the proposed service requirements for the communications satellite system in 1980, the then Minister for Post and Telecommunictions, Mr Staley, indicated that the satellite should facilitate 'arrangements conducive to the provision of a second homestead and community broadcasting service'. This was reiterated by the then Minister for Communications, Mr Sinclair, in May 1982 when he said that it was the Government's intention that the services provided by the satellite would include 'the use of a second homestead and community broadcasting satellite service'.

If the 30-watt transponders on the second satellite are allowed to be used for commercial broadcasting through a spot beam, people will be able to receive a commercial television service through the same earth station that they instal to pick up the ABC Homestead and Community Broadcasting Satellite Service. However, this Government in its wisdom has decided that this is not to be the case and that commercial broadcasting is to be allowed only through a national beam. That means that the strength of the signal from the 30-watt transponders will be greatly reduced so it will not be possible for the people in remote and regional areas to receive commercial television unless they can afford the large antenna costing in the region of $7,000. In any case, the signals are now to be encoded so they would be able to receive only the signals from approved stations and they would then have to be transmitted. As Mr Duffy admitted, quite simply this means that at this stage it will not be possible to receive direct broadcasts of commercial stations in the home via the satellites. This will come as a severe blow to the estimated 682,000 Australians who presently do not have access to commercial television. It would be particularly unfortunate for the people in my electorate of Western Australia which has a high percentage of its population living in isolated and remote parts of the State.

The Commonwealth Government's 1980 publication Atlas of Australian Resources presented an analysis of the population distribution. This separated three zones of concentration of population, with zone 3-the zone of sparce settlement- representing the zone with the lowest concentration of population. Interestingly , of all the States, Western Australia had the greatest percentage of its population living in zone 3. The figures were based on the 1976 census. At that time there were some 110,000 people living in zone 3 out of a total population in Western Australia of 1.1 million. Furthermore, the analysis showed that the number of people living in zone 3 had increased more quickly than in any other State. During the period 1971 to 1976 the number of people living in the sparcely settled zone increased by 4.2 per cent, compared with an increase of 2. 6 per cent in Queensland, and decreases in New South Wales and South Australia.

In quantitative terms, 42,000 people in Western Australia have no television service whatsoever. It is estimated that some 117,000 people receive no commercial television. Of course, in absolute terms we are talking about a small number of people. I concede that. However, it might be worth considering that many of the people who live in remote and isolated areas, and do so without many of the services that the rest of the community take for granted, contribute a great deal to the Australian community as a whole. Many are engaged in the production of mineral and other agricultural products which create wealth for the country quite disproportionate to the number of people involved. I suggest that there is a very great contrast between what these people contribute to the Australian community and what the Australian community contributes to them.

The decision regarding the allocation of the 30-watt transponders rests ultimately with Aussat Pty Ltd, which must take into account the Minister's guidelines which state that all transponder capacity allocated for commercial television must be in a national beam, and signals using this capacity must be encoded before transmission via satellite. The very likely outcome will be that the three major capital city networks will take up three of the transponders and use them to distribute programs to the regional stations. This task could be performed quite adequately by the 12-watt transponders. To allow use of the more powerful transponders for this purpose represents, in my view, a tragic waste of the satellite's capacity and a misallocation of its potential.

The Government has introduced a supplementary licence scheme, whereby a commercial television or radio station located outside a capital city may apply for one supplementary licence to provide an additional service in the same medium. This will increase the choice available to viewers who already receive a commercial television service but, as Mr Duffy admitted:
Unfortunately, supplementary stations are no advantage to the 200,000 households in remote areas who do not have even an original commercial television service.

The Government's argument for scrapping a commercial homestead and community broadcasting service, using the 30-watt transponders in a spot beam configuration, is that it would not a viable service for a commercial company to operate. Again, I quote Mr Duffy:
The thinly scattered population in remote areas is not financially attractive to advertiser-supported services.

Yet clearly they are people who disagree with the Government upon this point. In Western Australia, the Golden West Network Limited has submitted a proposal for a remote community television service which would involve leasing a 30-watt transponder in a spot beam configuration. The proposal of the Golden West Network would provide two alternative commercial television channels to Western Australians living in remote and regional areas. The network plans to use a mixture of programs from the major networks and a substantial amount of local news and content. In addition, the Western Australian Government, in its submission to the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal inquiry into the use of satellite program services, suggested that it would be possible to provide a commercial service to remote areas by forming a consortium of State Government and commercial interests. This consortium would share the use of a 30-watt transponder fixed in a spot beam. The submission from the Western Australian Government pointed out that it was people living in isolated areas who at present received only ABC television or no television at all 'that are most likely to be neglected in any commercial efforts to use satellite program services . . . as presently envisaged, namely where relatively weak signals from the satellite are received at many ''community'' stations, for later retransmission or for more or less instantaneous reradiation'. The only barrier to those schemes is the Government's refusal to allow commercial broadcasting via the satellite in a spot beam configuration. The other point I make in this regard concerns the delay on the part of the Government in deciding whether to allow some sort of pay television service, where viewers would pay a fee to receive television programs. I believe this is another choice which may be available to all Australians. However, I believe that the priority ought to be to provide free commercial television so that everyone in Australia has the choice of television viewing that already most people in Australia take for granted. In November the Minister for Communications stated:
Every Australian will have at least one commercial television service potentially available;

I would like to know exactly what he meant by that. Certainly under the restrictions that have been imposed, only people who now receive commercial television will benefit by possibly receiving a greater choice of channels under the supplementary licence scheme. Those people who already are out of range of their local television station's transmission range will not receive commercial television. Certainly the satellite provides the potential for all Australias to receive commercial television. This Government's policy has simply removed the means by which this can be done.

I turn now to the further section of the Bill that deals with the ownership of Aussat, namely, the decision of the Government to allow the sale of 25 per cent of the shares in Aussat to Telecom Australia. I make the observation that, of course, this is a reversal of the decision that was announced by Mr Keating, and I suspect supported by Senator Button, in the economic statement of May 1983. The then Government said that 49 per cent of its equity in Aussat Pty Ltd would be sold to allow private sector participation in the ownership of the satellite communications system.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why do you fix me with your bizarre speculation, Senator?

—I do not think it is speculation and I do not think it is bizarre, but if Senator Button wants to deny it categorically I will accept his word. Now we are told that Aussat will be retained as a separate Commonwealth-owned company and in addition Telecom will buy one quarter of the Government's 100 per cent shareholding. Clearly, the reason for this is to allow Telecom some measure of control over the development of satellite related services. However, surely it would have been possible for Telecom to obtain adequate protection through legislative provisions rather than squandering taxpayers' money in this venture. Indeed, this Bill already seeks to give Telecom a great deal of protection from potential competition. For example, the Bill will prevent Aussat from providing public switched telephone services and public switched data bases, thus confirming and preserving Telecom's monopoly in this area. It is hard to see where the necessity for a 25 per cent shareholding in Aussat by Telecom lies. To take up this shareholding will cost Telecom in the region of $19m. Surely this money would be far better spent in upgrading its terrestrial network.

SPEECH.PARA: In my State of Western Australia alone there are still some 412 customers-let us remember that an isolated homestead counts as just one customer so the number of people affected would be rather higher-who are still using one of the 64 manual exchanges in the State. One hundred and ninety-six customers have party lines. In addition, almost 200 people are at present on a waiting list of three months or more to have telephones installed.

The new digital radio concentrator system will undoubtedly effect great improvements in Telecom's ability to provide telephone services to people in isolated regions. As I understand it, Telecom has estimated that it will be possible to connect all the remote areas of Australia to the national automatic telecommunications network for a cost of some $400m. In my view Telecom would do better to concentrate its efforts and resources on this important work. One also wonders exactly where Telecom will find the funds to take up this 25 per cent shareholding. In the last financial year profits fell by $12m to $263m which represents only a 2.9 per cent return on capital investment. To find the money to buy into Aussat, it would seem to me that Telecom will either have to make cost savings and perhaps slow down its program of improvements to the terrestrial network, or increase its charges so that Telecom users will find themselves subsidising Telecom's shareholdings in Aussat.

Telecom has already increased its charges very substantially in the last few years. Since 1982 the cost of a local call has risen from 9c to 15c. Since 1981 the cost of renting a private telephone has risen from an annual charge of $85 to $115. Likewise, the cost of renting a business phone has risen from $120 a year to $190 a year. The latest of these increases came into effect in only October of last year.

I can see no justification for Telecom outlaying funds on Aussat and I am sure that Telecom's customers would much prefer, as would the great majority of Australians, to see this money used to keep down telephone charges. Certainly Telecom should be allowed to make some contribution to the future development of the satellite, but this does not require that it should own part of the company.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry and Commerce and Minister Assisting the Minister for Communications)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank honourable senators who have contributed to this debate with a series of wide-ranging observations about what is in fact a fairly simple piece of legislation. Listening to some of the speeches-I regret that sadly I did not have the opportunity to hear them all -I was reminded of that great story of Gertrude Stein on her death bed. She is alleged to have sat up in bed and said loudly: 'What is the answer? What is the answer?' She then said 'But of course, what is the question?', and fell back and died. In the course of the debate on this legislation there have been many of those sorts of rhetorical questions. It really is surprising, when one views the history of this matter. I will come to that in a minute.

SPEECH.PARA: Many of the specific questions, which I will not answer, relate to what the Government might do in the Budget about video programs for children and things of that kind. I do not think it is the responsibility of any Minister to try to answer those questions in the course of a debate on this legislation. Senator Kilgariff asked a number of rhetorical questions about what the satellite will do for people in the bush. I will come to that in a minute.

If one reflects on the history of the satellite it had rather the same sorts of characteristics about it as the history of the film incentives, for example. Allegedly that scheme was suggested to the former Prime Minister by a make-up girl at Channel 7 and it subsequently became government policy. In fact, if one looks at the history of the satellite, the idea was suggested to the former Government by Kerry Packer who commissioned the Bond report. If one goes back to that report one will find many promises about the sorts of services that the satellite might provide to people in the bush. Those non-government proponents of the satellite really did beat up a whole series of suggestions in support of otherwise dubious arguments in favour of Australia having a satellite. The history of the development of the satellite up to the stage of this legislation, or until quite recently, has really been a chaotic one in which the promises have been made, the details not adequately considered--

TALK.START.PARA: —Expectations lifted too high.

—I agree that expectations were lifted too high. Indeed, I might unfairly characterise it as an extraordinary example of planning whereby one actually gets to the stage of technical development of the satellite proposal without at that stage realising what the market is for its services. I would have thought that one would begin by trying to assess the market and then go to planning of the service which would provide satisfaction in the market, rather than the other way round which in fact is what has happened with the development of this project.

SPEECH.PARA: In remote areas, of course, the satellite will ensure services by radio and by the Australian Broadcasting Corporation television service to a lot of people who currently do not obtain those services. I think it is fair to say that it is not possible to put it higher than to say that, in providing an extra facility in the telecommunications system, it is possible that in the future it will enable the provision of a wider range of services to people in remote areas than if the satellite had not been there, but sometimes at considerable cost and at considerable technical difficulty. That is something for the future. Of course it will, in terms of its very existence, improve the services available to people in the outback, which I suppose was the burden of Senator Kilgariff's speech. There are all sorts of speculations about what might happen in relation to the provision of extra services to remote communities. I do not think it is fair to say that the promises to which Senator Kilgariff referred were made by people in this Government. There was a lot of wild speculation early in the history of the development of the satellite proposal.

The essential features of this Bill, which if I might say so not uncharitably were scarcely the topic of debate in the Senate, establish the ownership and management structure of and particularly the shareholding arrangements for Aussat Pty Ltd. Secondly, the features can perhaps be described as integrating the telecommunications service by Telecom Australia and Aussat into one network. I think the point about integration is of great importance because at an early stage of planning of the satellite proposal not much coherent thought was really given to the question of integration of the services which are provided by the satellite and the services which are provided terrestrially by Telecom. I think the provision of that degree of integration is an important aspect of that legislation. That degree of integration is reflected in part in the provisions relating to ownership and the 25 per cent Telecom shareholding in Aussat.

I think the third feature of the legislation which is important and which also relates to that same issue is that the regulation of third party traffic on the satellite will be along the same lines as existing Telecom regulations in relation to existing services. I think that in a sense those three important points in the legislation all go to that one question of the importance of integrating the two systems into one telecommunications service for the benefit of all Australians. I think there will be great benefits in that. I do not want to anticipate a whole series of questions next time around by making promises about when and to what extent those services will be able to be delivered.

One other comment I would like to make is that many honourable senators have raised a whole range of issues relating to their approval or otherwise of Telecom. A number of important issues were raised regarding telecommunications policy, many of which were dealt with in the report of the Davidson Public Inquiry into Telecommunication Services in Australia. That committee looked at Telecom. I just make the point that when people talk about the charges and the profits made by Telecom and so on it should not be forgotten that Telecom is there to provide a community service. It does provide a community service. It does provide a community service. In particular it provides a community service to people in the remote areas of Australia by way of cross-subsidisation of the very expensive services which are delivered to those communities. I do not think that those issues should be forgotten in the course of a debate of this kind. I remind Opposition senators that while the Government of the day dithered over the recommendations of the Davidson committee of inquiry-I think it is fair to say that the responses of the then Government were as coherent as the Opposition 's current responses on wages policy-many of these essential issues in regard to the provision of telecommunications services in Australia were potentially overlooked. I do not think that in 1984 we should go through that same process again.

The Government is not particularly concerned about Senator Baume's amendment to the motion that the Bills be read a second time. The amendment, in part, seeks to add to that motion an opinion of the Senate. That opinion simply is that the services provided by the Australian Telecommunicatons Commission and partnerships entered into by the Commission be subject to the same tax and dividend requirements as competing commercial companies. I think that is a very sensible opinion. Whether the Government follows that sensible opinion or not will be determined at the appropriate time. There are things to be said on both sides of the argument in relation to that issue and I do not want to canvass the issue beyond that at this stage. If the Senate wants to express that opinion I have no dubt that the Government will take notice of it in any decision it makes about this matter. I thank honourable senators who have contributed to the debate and I commend to the Senate the second reading of these two Bills.
Amendment agreed to.
Original question, as amended, resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: (Quorum formed)

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —As there are amendments to both the Satellite Communications Bill 1984 and the Satellite Communications ( Consequential Amendments) Bill 1984, is it the wish of the Committee that the Bills be considered separately? There being no objection, it is so ordered.

INTERJECT.PARA: Clauses 1 to 7-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 3, clause 8, sub-clause (1), after paragraph (c), add the following new paragraphs:
'(d) of a commercial television service for people in remote communities and dwellings in Australia; and
(e) of a commercial broadcasting service for people in remote communities and dwellings in Australia.'.

Clause 8 stipulates that the directors shall carry out certain functions. The Government has dropped one of the Opposition's prime objectives for Aussat, namely, that of providing remote areas with commercial radio and television services. Our amendment seeks to include provision of commercial television broadcasting services for people who live in remote communities and dwellings. Honourable senators who spoke in the second reading debate drew attention to the problems involved in the narrow choice of the phrase 'remote Australia' and pointed to the desirability of giving directions to the directors of Aussat that these functions shall be provided. The Opposition believes that it is the right of every Australian to have as wide a choice of services as possible. If it is possible to make the choice broader than the excellent service provided by the Australian Broadcasting Corporation, the Opposition believes that such services should be made available to the public. In our view, this satellite will afford such an opportunity.

The previous Government proposed four zones with high powered transponders on the second satellite, or a mix between the two satellites on spot beam, to cover Australia with a free commercial service. My colleague Senator Teague drew attention to some of the problems which remain unresolved on the topic of national versus regional services as to the proper way in which regional services would operate. But that is not the threshold issue. That issue is whether commercial services should be made available.

The Opposition believes that the Government, having taken a decision on the transponders with reference to satellite program services to the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal have probably made it impossible for free commercial television services to be provided in the cheapest and simplest way possible. We believe that the people in remote Australia-non-metropolitan Australia-deserve some commitment to commercial television and commercial radio as well as receiving the excellent ABC services. I commend the amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Democrats commend the Opposition on moving this amendment. However, my party cannot support the amendment for reasons I gave in my second reading speech, plus the brief comments which I shall now make. The Opposition amendment alters the obligations of Aussat to include the provision of full commercial broadcasting and television services to remote areas. That is a commendable idea and indeed is the rationale behind the satellite. However, the provision of a free commercial service does not satisfy the requirement of specialised and relevant broadcasting for remote communities. We believe that there are options for broadcasters using the satellite other than existing commercial operators which would better serve the interests of remote communities. It is a savage indictment that remote communities will have to wait until about 1986 or 1987 for relevant broadcasting. In our view, that service should not now be compromised by creating an obligation that it has to be commercial. We understand the thrust of the Opposition amendment but, for the reasons I have given, the Democrats cannot support it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry and Commerce and Minister Assisting the Minister for Communications)

TALK.START.PARA: —The legislation contains no prohibitions on the development of commercial services on the satellite for remote communities. The Opposition's intention in seeking to include such a proposal in this Bill is unnecessary, however commendable in motherhood terms it might be. The purpose of this clause is designed to ensure that the public interest aspects of the satellite transmissions are met and that the obligation is placed squarely on the directors in terms of their responsibilities.

SPEECH.PARA: The clause requires that the Australian Broadcasting Corporation, the Department of Aviation and Telecom Australia be given priority in satellite capacity. They are essential government services which have been much lauded in debate in the Senate in the last few hours. To place commercial broadcasting on the same footing as an essential public service as provided in the clause would elevate it, however highly one might think of the commercial broadcasting services, to a position that is not justified. It would not be appropriate for the objects of providing commercial broadcasting to remote areas to be included in this clause of the Bill.

The Government is fully aware of the fact that the satellite might at an appropriate time provide commercial broadcasting services to remote communities. The Government is currently examining how this can be done and decisions on this matter should be publicly available at some time in the latter half of this year . In using satellite technology, as with the existing Australian telecommunications technology, one is concerned with add-on arrangements in terms of services. They all involve additional planning and costs. The Government is mindful of that factor, and does not want in this legislation to be saddled with an obligation which is put in motherhood terms. For those reasons the amendment is not acceptable.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Peter Baume's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: Clause agreed to.
Proposed new clause 8A.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 3, after clause 8, insert the following new clause:
'Directors of Aussat
8A. (1) In this section-
'Commissioner' means-
(a) the Managing Director of the Commission; or
(b) another Commissioner holding office under section 22 of the Telecommunications Act 1975;
'prescribed person' means-
(a) a Commissioner; or

(b) a person holding an office in the Service that is higher than any office in the Service held by a person who is principally responsible for the management of the affairs of the Commission in a State;
'Service' means the Australian Telecommunications Commission Service established by section 38 of the Telecommunications Act 1975.
(2) At any time-
(a) the Directors of Aussat shall not include more than 2 persons who are, or, within the period of 3 years immediately preceding their appointment, have been, prescribed persons; and
(b) at least three-quarters of the Directors of Aussat shall be persons other than persons who are, or, within that period, have been, prescribed persons.'.

The amendment relates to the number of directors of Aussat Pty Ltd. If the number of directors increases from the present number of 11, there is a provision that at least three quarters of those directors shall be persons other than Telecom-related prescribed persons. The whole thrust of the amendment, as I said in my speech on the second reading, is to limit the number of Telecom or Telecom-related directors to two persons out of the current 11. As I said, if that number increases beyond 11 there is provision to cover that. The Bill already contains a provision that the shareholding by Telecom in Aussat cannot exceed 25 per cent. Any amendment to that situation has to be approved by the Parliament; it cannot be made by regulation. This amendment shores up the other danger of a takeover by Telecom in that its management, in the form of the number of directors on the board, cannot exceed 25 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition supports the amendment which has been moved by the Australian Democrats. We believe, for the reasons set out by Senator Chipp, that it is a suitable amendment. As we have made clear, we would prefer a different relationship between Telecom and Aussat.
—So would we.
—So would the Australian Democrats, but given the situation we face this amendment seems to have merit and it will have the support of the Opposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry and Commerce and Minister Assisting the Minister for Communications)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman--
—Come on, let's have consensus with a big 'C'.
—Right, we agree too.

SPEECH.PARA: Proposed new clause agreed to.
Clauses 9 and 10-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 11 (Shares of Aussat).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 3, clause 11, lines 24 to 39, leave out the clause, insert the following clause:
'11. (1) Shares in Aussat are not capable of being held by any person other than- (a) the Commonwealth;
(b) a person as trustee for the Commonwealth; or
(c) such non-statutory corporation, entity, or person as may be prescribed.
(2) Each share in Aussat shall be issued with the same rights and restrictions with regard to voting.

(3) No shares in Aussat can be sold or transferred unless a statement of the proposed sale or transfer has been laid before each House of the Parliament and the proposed sale or transfer has been approved by resolution of each House of the Parliament.
(4) Any issue, sale or transfer of shares, or any arrangement or agreement, that is contrary to this section is void and of no effect.'

The amendment is in line with the sentiments raised during the second reading debate. We are concerned about the proposal to offer some shareholding to Telecom Australia and we wish to retain Aussat Pty Ltd as a private company with the shares completely owed by the Commonwealth and without any shares held by Telecom. Although I did not point this out during the second reading, debate, the role of Telecom throughout the last few years has been a most interesting one. It lobbied very hard initially to prevent the satellite project proceeding and it did all it could to obstruct the setting up of Aussat and the whole establishment of the projects. Having failed in that it then sought to reverse its ground and did a real Sir Humphrey act. Having failed there it wanted to take over the whole operation. Having tried to obstruct it and to have the whole satellite operation contained within Telecom and having failed, it came back to see whether it could control Aussat. During the debate I quoted certain Press releases which were issued by Labor Party spokesmen in the late 1970s. I am sure that they were prompted by pressure from Telecom putting a certain view about the whole Aussat proposal.

TALK.START.PARA: —Or by the Telecom union.

—And/or by the Telecom union. We have some documents from the Telecom union which make quite clear what its proposal is and what its view is. Certain people are talking about the acquisition of power and the using of power. We can understand what has gone on in those kind of terms. We simply believe that it is not appropriate and we think it is not necessary for Telecom to be a shareholder in Aussat. We think that that arrangement gives power to Telecom over the operations, the future and the development of Aussat. We think it is more appropriate for the ownership of that company to remain either completely with the Government or, as we proposed when we were in government, with some form of private shareholding. I understand the point that Senator Chipp made in the debate, that his Party had considered the same proposition and it had concerns as to how that private equity would be granted and whether one could get past the use of nominees to concentrate ownership. I understand that problem and I do not believe that it could not be resolved.
—It has not been resolved properly for the ownership of television stations, has it?

—I still think we could have resolved it and built sanctions within the legislation had we gone down that road. We cannot see any really rational reason for the Government to have proceeded as it has. We think the revised decision by the Government with respect to ownership of the satellite is a measure of the power which the particular union has over Government members and Caucus and therefore over the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: It is widely known that the ATEA, the Australian Telecommunications Employees Association, wants to protect its position of power over the provision of telecommunications services in Australia and, of course, that power is weakened to the extent that the Aussat system does not come within the purview of its union. It has undertaken intense lobbying and it has been able to reverse the statement and the commitment made by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) last year in his May statement, the mini-Budget statement, when he confirmed that 49 per cent of the shareholding of the satellite would be sold to the private sector. This is just one of many policy reversals. It is a matter which we believe is wrong as a method of government operation, and to that extent we think it is wrong in principle. Because of that we have moved amendment No. (2), which has been circulated in the name of the Opposition, which seeks to leave out clause 11, lines 24 to 39, and to insert certain other words which have the effect of restricting the ownership in the way in which I have set out in this speech to the Committee. I commend the amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Temporary Chairman, the Leader of the Opposition, Senator Button, set a magnificent example of brevity in his last response which I would like to follow.
—You have set a magnificent example of inaccuracy in describing me as the Leader of the Opposition. We have been here for 13 months now.

—Yes. I stand quite properly rebuked and I ask the Leader of the Government to forgive me. But for reasons I gave in my speech at the second reading stage, although we sympathise very much with the sentiments and everything that Senator Peter Baume has said on behalf of the Opposition, the Democrats cannot support the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry and Commerce and Minister Assisting the Minister for Communications)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government will not accept this amendment. The actual effect of it would be to allow the sale of shares to private shareholders up to 100 per cent and, of course, to exclude participation by Telecom Australia or by statutory authorities in the ownership of Aussat Pty Ltd. I do not know what Senator Baume is talking about when he says that on the one hand the Opposition thinks Aussat should be fully owned by the Government- 100 per cent-which is what he said a minute or two ago, and on the other hand he says we can have an optional policy which involves 50, 51 or 49 per cent owned by private enterprise or, for that matter, 100 per cent. I think it is extraordinary that an amendment should be moved like this and supported by comments like that. The Opposition is saying: We will have anything rather than what the Government has proposed. 'We have no idea what, but anything will do rather than what the Government has proposed'.

SPEECH.PARA: I just make the point again that I made in the second reading debate: If the satellite-imposed on this country by a series of ad hoc decisions made in haste rather than in quiet reflection, made in terms of grandiose speculations about the benefits which would be provided rather than serious assessments-which has been thrust upon us and which this Government inherited is to operate successfully, it must do so as part of an integrated telecommunications network. It cannot do so in terms of two rival systems, totally divorced in terms of ownership, competing in terms of this most valuable resource, the provision of telecommunications services. It must be, to use Senator Chipp's phrase of a few minutes ago, a consensual arrangement, a co-operative arrangement, between Aussat and Telecom. We do not in any way retreat-and I do not want anything I said earlier to be taken as a sign of retreat-from the benefits which the satellite can provide to Australia in terms of provision of the most up to date telecommunications services. But those benefits cannot be fully gained with an amorphous sort of ownership structure, as suggested by the Opposition. They can be gained only by the integrated approach which the Government has developed both in relation to the development of the services and the ownership and management of the satellite.

TALK.START.PARA: —With respect, what you are saying does not differ essentially from what Senator Baume is saying.

—Oh, yes it does, Senator. The Government's proposition is quite simply about the ownership of the satellite. It provides for a 25 per cent ownership by Telecom and the remaining 75 per cent to be held by the Government. The purpose of the 25 per cent ownership by Telecom and indeed the purpose of the honourable senator's own amendment in a sense, Senator Chipp, is to provide that there is a sensible integration of management at the board level in Aussat. What Senator Baume is saying is: 'We, the Opposition, do not like that arrangement and we suggest a few optional bargain basement alternatives'.
—Which was your original position, with great respect.

—I am not talking about anybody's original position, I am talking about what is in the legislation. We were offered a couple of alternatives which there is no clarity about and which do not in any sense ensure any integration between the two arms of the telecommunications system. That is what we are concerned to do. The amendment is not accepted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I really must respond to what was a most non-logical argument; it was simply not logical.
—Try 'illogical'.

—Well, illogical, if honourable senators wish. But there has been no really coherent argument as to why the integrated approach the Government holds so essential in April 1984 is the one that must be preferred.

—Whereas in May 1983, which is precisely the point Senator Chipp is making, the Government propounded with equal fervour a different proposition, in fact the one that we believe still is the more appropriate one. The only logical reason we can see is that the Government was giving way in the face of pressure from the union involved and there has been no real argument or demonstration as to why this integration, which was not present in 1983, is now so essential in 1984.

SPEECH.PARA: Secondly, Senator Button has criticised the form of this amendment as permitting ownership up to any per cent by private individuals. I think he should read the amendment. First of all, it merely provides a framework within which the shareholding can take place. But if one reads further through that amendment, at all stages it requires government decision, government action and parliamentary acquiescence to any course that is proposed. Of course this would permit any individuals to hold any shares, even with this legislation in place, only if it was the wish of the Government so to proceed. It says so quite explicitly. First of all clause 11 (1) (c) refers to such non-statutory corporation, entity or person as may be prescribed. So unless bodies or individuals are prescribed they cannot hold shares. Secondly, it goes on to state:

No shares . . . can be sold or transferred unless a statement of the proposed sale or transfer has been laid before each House of the Parliament and the proposed sale or transfer has been approved by resolution of each House of the Parliament.

This is nothing that can be done without the acquiescence of government. It requires both Houses of Parliament to agree. Control stays with the Government. The clause goes on to say that any sale or transfer of shares contrary to this section is void and of no effect. So all we are trying to do is provide a framework and say that the Government then controls what happens subsequently. That is why I drew a number of alternative possibilities. I still believe that the amendment proposed is a desirable amendment, and the Opposition will press it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Sen The Hon D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition supports the Quarantine Amendment Bill. I shall spend only a few moments in talking on this measure. It is probably necessary and proper to make one or two observations about this quarantine Bill if for no other reason than that quarantine is of importance to a vast island continent such as Australia. Only a day or so ago the Senate was talking about the need for surveillance in relation to defence, against terrorist activity, illegal immigration, drug running, and so on. We have to be just as alert in the surveillance of our coastline to maintain quarantine arrangements. Australia is an island continent. We have massive sea lanes of communication. Our economy is very significantly dependent on healthy stock and healthy plant life. Therefore we need to establish a quarantine system that maintains that healthy stock and plant life.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill basically seeks to increase the penalties currently imposed. They have not been increased for some five or six years, and I believe that the Bill increases them quite properly and quite severely. In the case of individuals, the Bill seeks to increase fines from a maximum of $10,000 to $50,000. It seeks to increase gaol sentences from five years to 10 years. Both penalties may apply . In the case of a corporate body, the maximum penalty is to be raised to a fine of $200,000. One only has to contemplate the horrific effects of the outbreak of any of a number of diseases in our animals to realise the enormous consequences that that would have on the economy of this country. If foot and mouth disease, which has occurred in a number of countries around the world, were to break out in this country it would probably denude the agricultural or primary industrial economy of something like $2.5 billion in the first year. Its ultimate effects are hard to evaluate because such a disease would be not only disastrous in that it would kill a vast number of our livestock but also it would make great inroads into the bloodstock lines and into the breeding capacities which have taken generations to establish. The real and ultimate losses of such a circumstance can be imagined and seen to be of enormous consequence in that field.

I believe it is unfortunate that at the moment the amount of aerial surveillance which is carried out in Australia has been reduced. We have lost the operation of the Nomad aircraft with its 360 degree radar search capacity. That is a serious blow to our capacity to observe and tighten the quarantine controls in this country. If Australia is not protected from the outbreak of disease it will not only mean significant loss to one or two specific industries but also it will have an equally disastrous effect on employment, particularly in the northern parts of Australia.

The legislation carries out a number of virtually administrative procedures which improve the operation of the quarantine laws, and it is to be commended on that ground. For instance, it rationalises the appointment of quarantine inspectors. Only the Director of Quarantine and chief quarantine officers will now be appointed by the Minister, the rest of the staff can be appointed by the Director. This, of course, simplifies the procedure and has to be seen as more efficient.

I remind the Senate that it was the observation of the Australian Labor Party at around election time that the quarantine management of animal and plant life should be transferred from the Department of Health to the Department of Primary Industry. To date that has not occurred. I must agree that such a transfer would appear to be a thoroughly acceptable and logical move. I express the hope that in the months that follow the Government will increase its attention to the Australian National Animal Health Laboratory which was established at Geelong. That is an organisation, an institution, of the very highest level of capacity in the scientific evaluation of the problems that relate to animal diseases. It is a laboratory which, when it reaches its maximum capacity, will be an institution of world-wide renown and acknowledgement. With those few observations, I express again the support of the Opposition for the Quarantine Amendment Bill and wish it a speedy passage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Opposition for its support of the Quarantine Amendment Bill. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I wish to speak briefly in the adjournment debate on a matter which is of considerable concern in the Northern Territory-alcohol abuse. The Northern Territory has a crime problem almost 500 per cent higher than that of the national rate. Eighty per cent of this crime is alcohol-related. The Northern Territory Government has taken a number of initiatives to combat this problem. One, of course, was the introduction of the Northern Territory Criminal Code which has specific provisions dealing with alcohol-related crime. I am sure that the Northern Territory Government was pleased with the Federal Government's change of attitude regarding some of these sections of the Criminal Code. In particular, it was pleasing to see the Federal Government accept the provision that accused persons seeking to rely on the defence of intoxication should be presumed, evidentially, to have foreseen the reasonable consequences of their actions; and that if they want to use intoxication as a defence they should be required to give credible evidence to that effect.

SPEECH.PARA: The Northern Territory Department of Health has also taken a number of steps aimed at combating the abuse of alcohol in the Northern Territory. In a few minutes I will seek leave to have a section of the Health Department's 1982-83 report incorporated in Hansard. This section deals specifically with some of the measures taken by the Department. It also gives morbidity, mortality and perinatal statistics for that year. Among the activities of the Health Department has been the establishment of a Drug and Alcohol Bureau. This co- ordinates the many government and non-government endeavours in drug and alcohol treatment and rehabilitation. It also has the ability to provide research and evaluation expertise to assist the Government in developing well informed policies. The Health Department has continued with its education campaign ' Boozers are Losers' which was launched in 1981-82. This, in conjuction with an alcohol and drug education program which has been introduced in Territory schools, has raised public awareness of the problems associated with drugs and alcohol.

The Territory Government has also introduced a number of liquor control measures which are summarised in the papers I am about to seek leave to have incorporated . The Drug and Alcohol Bureau, along with other agencies, is evaluating these measures to discover what impact they have on the various sections of the Territory community. I seek leave to have these papers incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The papers read as follows-

The NT Drug and Alcohol Bureau has also been established in order to better co- ordinate the many Government and non-Government endeavours at treatment and rehabilitation, as well as provide research and evaulation expertise that can be used to develop informed policies in this much debated area.

A major public education campaign, the ''Boozers are Losers'' campaign, was launched in 1981/82 to raise public awareness of this issue, and the Education Department has introduced a core-curriculum component on alcohol and drug education into its school programme.
Through the Health Department's Grants-in-Aid programme, community initiatives have developed at a rapid rate and more are in the pipeline.

What is evident, so far, is that, like so many other social welfare issues, the legislation component of intervention/prevention/treatment packages tends to inconvenience the many in order to treat, assist or protect the few. As with vehicle seat belt legislation, most of those whom it affects do not experience its benefits since most drivers do not have accidents. The Northern Territory is in a position of taking initiatives in the face of mounting alcohol related problems that do and will impact on the community at large while, in many cases, benefiting only the few.
The impact of the five liquor control measures discussed above, can be summarised as follows:

(a) The licensing provisions of the Liquor Act have raised the standards of licensed premises in the Northern Territory, and have allowed the public easier access to the licensing and review processes.

(b) The restricted areas provisions of the Liquor Act have had a beneficial impact in some localities, whereas in others they do not appear to have worked. The most important feature of this initiative is that the option is open for communities to use these provisions, if they chose to do so.

(c) Sobering-up facilities for people intoxicated in public are still too recent a development for any evaulative comment to be made. This approach to public drunkenness, however, places a high priority on the welfare of the individual in contrast to the punitive measures that are often espoused for dealing with 'self-inflicted' conditions, such as drunkenness.

(d) The amendment of the takeaway liquor trading hours has not been received well by the liquor industry nor by those sectors of the public which are inconvenienced by this restriction. No evidence has yet been submitted, however, demonstrating that the industry has been harmed by these changes to the trading hours. On the other hand, some health and welfare agencies have expressed strong support for the changes.

(e) The public drinking legislation, otherwise known as the ''two kilometre law '', has been by far the most controversial of the Government's initiatives. The public response has been similar to that seen on the introduction of random breath testing in 1979. Public drinking has decreased in the Northern Territory following the implementation of the two kilometre law. The protective custody rate has also fallen.

Public drinking has been a feature of the Territory way of life that has long made an impression on visitors. The range and number of activities that Territorians engaged in with a can or stubby in hand were enormous-running, jumping, riding and walking. There is no doubt that such deeply entrenched practices contributed significantly to the large public drunkenness problem. The two kilometre law may focibly change such practices and in the process effect an attitudinal change to drinking practices and behaviour.

Evaluations of the liquor control measures discussed above are being conducted by the Drug and Alcohol Bureau and other agencies. They aim to show clearly just what impact the initiatives have had on the various sections of the Northern Territory community. Following the submission of the evaluation reports, the responsibility will be with government, once again, to assess, from its perspective, the balance between the costs of such initiatives and their benefits.
