SPEECH.PARA: I would like to commend the people who are working in the field, particularly the co-ordinator, the Aboriginal person who is in charge of the Aboriginal health workers, the health aides, and the very many dedicated doctors and nurses who work in the field and in the hospitals in the outback endeavouring to bring about better statistics, or at least to cut down the number of deaths of Aboriginal children.

I talked previously about the haves and the have nots. It is a long hard road to better health for Aboriginal children in the outback. Conditions are still very poor. As the figures indicate, in 1982 infection resulted in the death of many Aboriginal children. Their living conditions are poor. The only way this can be really improved is by governments. The Federal Government is doing well as is the Territory Government. They have to give more assistance to the Aboriginal people in the field. The advent of Aboriginal health aides is helping tremendously. They are working amongst their own people, and with encouragement and more facilities I am sure we will see the infant mortality figure decrease. But it will be a long hard road. This is a report of activity in the Northern Territory but the statistics in this brief report are of national interest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise an aspect of the policy associated with the administration of Commissioner for Housing loans in the Australian Capital Territory. It relates to the case of a woman attempting to obtain an additional loan, for which in principle she is eligible, to enable her to buy out her husband's interest in the house. She is obliged to pay him the sum of $5000 thereby to retain the house for herself and her children. The present mortgage is $23,000 and that would then raise the mortgage to $28,000. Taking into account her income, excluding maintenance, she would be eligible only for a mortgage of $21,000, as the guidelines presently stand. Taking into account the maintenance and her other income, she would be eligible for $29,000 which is more than the amount she requires.

SPEECH.PARA: On the face of it, if the Department will not take into account the maintenance she faces having to sell the house, paying her husband $5,000 and not having enough left to buy a house for herself and the children. At present she would find it extremely difficult to get any other accomodation. In the private rental market she just would not have the income to be able to rent. In a letter she states:
. . . the Minister for Territories and Local Government-who has a policy of not evicting people for non-payment of rents but would deny my children the opportunity of a loving and secure home.

The situation is that the Department of Social Security takes into account maintenance payments when assessing other payments made to a sole parent, but the Department of Territories and Local Government will not take that figure into account in this situation, which is quite a different situation from any other sort of mortgage loan; it is specifically designed in a sense to ensure that children can stay in their home if possible. I realise that there has to be a cut-off point in any rules at some point but it seems to me that she cannot get that money on the one hand because the Department of Social Security does take it into account and on the other hand she cannot get the additional money she needs to secure her home because the other Department will not take that into account.

Julie Elliott, who has written to me, is concerned about her future and her children's future. She certainly believes that she has the capacity to cope with this loan, probably by going without to a fair extent at this stage at least. It seems to be a sufficiently border case. Maintenance is excluded from the calculations in one department but included in another. Maybe this matter ought to be reviewed given that this aspect of the policy, as I understand it, is in part to do with assisting people to retain the home in the event of a matrimonial breakdown.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will refer all the matters raised tonight by honourable senators to the respective Ministers. But, as it happens, I have a personal interest in all of them so I will give the Senate the benefit of my brief comments. Senator Kilgariff raised first of all the matter of alcohol related problems in the Northern Territory and the new Northern Territory ordinance. I will certainly raise that matter with the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans). I will raise the matter of the infant mortality rate in the Northern Territory with Dr Blewett, the Minister for Health. I make the personal comment that infant mortality has almost an exact correlation with the standard of living of the people affected. The best thing we can do for the Aboriginal community in the Northern Territory and elsewhere is not only to provide the assistance necessary to overcome the sorts of infections that Senator Kilgariff talked about but also, in the long run, raise the standard of living so that infant mortality rate goes down in correlation.

SPEECH.PARA: I was interested in Senator Reid's case because I have recently had a case with which I was personally involved concerning almost exactly the same situation with the Department of Territories and Local Government and the Commissioner for Housing loan. As Senator Reid says that Department ignores maintenance payments whereas my Department, the Department of Social Security, takes them into account. This crucial disregard of maintenance payments can in fact make the difference whether someone gets a loan or not. That is terribly important. I agree with her that it is much more important to keep people in the home in which they have been living and enable them to maintain themselves in that home rather than their having to sell out and go into what is a very rigid and difficult private rental market at the moment. Therefore, I will certainly, as a follow up to the sorts of cases I have had, take up Senator Reid's example with the Minister for Territories and Local Government in the hope that we can sort out what seems to me anyhow, superficially at least, to be an anomaly in the system. But in any case I will take all matters up with the relevant Ministers.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Special Minister of State, upon notice, on 29 February 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it possible under the new electoral provisions for a company, organisation or individual to make a sizeable donation to a political party or candidate and deliberately fail to notify the Australian Electoral Commission of that donation, without fear of detection.
(2) Is the Special Minister of State confident that any such attempts to avoid disclosure of political donations would be detected and thwarted.
(3) Would the investigation of these offences be the responsibility of the Australian Federal Police.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Special Minister of State has provided the following answers to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (2) and (3) Under section 153J of the Commonwealth Electoral Act, agents of parties and candidates have the responsibility of furnishing returns which disclose the total amount and number of gifts received over a specified period. The period which applies to political parties is from the day after polling day in the previous election until the expiration of polling day in the election after which the return is furnished.

In the case of a donation of $1,000 or more to a party and of $200 or more to a candidate, the return furnished by the agent must disclose the amount or value of the gift, the date on which it was made and the name and address of the donor . In the case of a donor making several gifts in the period covered by the return, the relevant details will be disclosed if the total value of those gifts is $1,000 or more in the case of gifts to a party or $200 or more in the case of gifts to a candidate.

In addition, section 153K of the Act requires that a person or organisation which during the election period makes a gift of $1,000 or more to a political party or candidate is required to furnish a similar return to that provided by the political party; that is, a 'front' organisation which makes a sizeable donation during the election period is required to give details of any gifts of $1,000 or more received by it during that period.

Section 153L provides that it is unlawful for a political party to receive a gift of $100 or more unless the name and address of the person making the gift are known to the person receiving the gift, or the gift is received on the condition that it be used for a purpose other than one related to an election or by-election. Similarly, it is unlawful for a candidate to receive an anonymous gift of $200 or more. Where an unlawful gift is received, an equivalent amount is payable to the Commonwealth.

The Act confers on the Commission very extensive powers in relation to the investigation of possible breaches of the funding and disclosure provisions and the accuracy of returns. An officer authorised by the Commission may serve a notice on a person requiring that person to produce documents or to give evidence relating to the commission, or possible commission, of an offence, or to matters set out in a claim or return. In certain circumstances an authorised officer may apply to a magistrate for the issue of a search warrant to seize things that may afford evidence relating to the commission of an offence. In these circumstances the Commission would have a variety of options including seeking the assistance of the Australian Federal Police.

Fines of up to $5,000 for an agent of a party and $1,000 for any other person are provided for failure to furnish a return within the required time. A further fine of $100 per day is provided for late returns. Fines of up to $10,000 for the agent of a party and up to $5,000 for any other person are provided for knowingly providing false or misleading particulars in a return (see section 153V).
